div1.p: AS IT IS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL IN DRURY-LANE.
LONDON: PRINTED FOR T. BECKET, IN THE STRAND. 1774.

div1.head: PREFACE.
div1.p: THE Author of the following performance cannot commit it to the press, without acknowledging the deepest sense of gratitude, for the uncommon marks of approbation with which he has been honoured by the Public.

Tho' he has chosen a title us'd by MOLIERE, he has neither borrowed a single circumstance from that great poet, nor to the best of his recollection from any other writer.—His chief study has been to steer between the extremes of sentimental gloom, and the excesses of uninteresting levity; he has some laugh, yet he hopes he has also some lesson; and fashionable as it has been lately for the wits,
even with his friend Mr. Garrick at their head, to ridicule the Comic Muse, when a little grave, he must think that she degenerates into farce, where the grand business of instruction is neglected, and consider it as a heresy in criticism, to say that one of the most arduous tasks within the reach of literature, shou'd, when executed; be wholly without utility.

The Author having been presumptuous enough to assert, that he has not purloin'd a single sprig of bays from the brow of any other writer, he may, perhaps, be ask'd, if there are not several plays in the English language, which, before his, produced Generals, Lawyers, Irishmen, Duels, Masquerades, and Mistakes? He answers, yes; and confesses moreover, that all the Comedies before his, were compos'd not only of men and women, but that before his, the great business of comedy consisted in making difficulties for the purpose of removing them; in distressing poor young lovers; and in rendering a happy marriage the object of every catastrophe.

Yet tho' the Author of the School for Wives, pleads guilty to all these charges, still, in extenuation of his offence, he begs leave to observe, that having
only men and women to introduce upon the stage, he was oblig'd to compose his Dramatis Personae of mere flesh and blood; if, however, he has thrown this flesh and this blood, into new situations; if he has given a new fable, and plac'd his characters in a point of light hitherto unexhibited:—he flat.ters himself that he may call his play, a new play, and tho' it did not exist before the creation of the world, like the famous Welch pedigree, that he may have some small pretensions to originality.

Two things besides the general moral inculcated thro' his piece, the Author has attempted; the first, to rescue the law, as a profession, from ridicule or obliquy; and the second, to remove the imputation of a barbarous ferocity, which dramatic writers, even meaning to compliment the Irish nation, have connected with their Idea of that gallant people:—The law, like every other profession, may have members who occasionally disgrace it; but to the glory of the British name, it is well know that in the worst of times, it has produced numbers whose virtues reflected honour upon human nature; many of the noblest privileges the constitution has to boast of, were derived from the integrity, or the wisdom of lawyers:
Yet the stage has hitherto cast an indiscriminate stigma upon the whole body, and laboured to make that profession either odious or contemptible in the theatre, which, if the laws are indeed dear to good Englishmen, can never be too much respected in this kingdom. There is scarcely a play in which a lawyer is introduced, that is not a libel upon the long robe; and so ignorant have many dramatic writers been, that they have made no distinction whatever, between the characters of the first Barristers in Westminster-Hall, and the meanest solicitors at the Old Bailey.

With respect to the gentlemen of Ireland, where even an absolue attempt is manifested, to place them in a favourable point of view, they are drawn with a brutal promptitude to quarrel, which is a disgrace to the well known humanity of their country.—The gentlemen of Ireland have doubtless a quick sense of honour, and, like the gentlemen of England, as well as like the gentlemen of every other high-spirited nation, are perhaps unhappily too ready to draw the sword, where they conceive themselves injured—But to make them proud of a barbarous propensity to Duelling; to make them actually delight in the effusion of blood, is to fasten a very unjust reproach upon their general character, and to render
them universally obnoxious to society. The author of the School for Wives therefore, has given a different picture of Irish manners, though in humble life, and flatters himself that those who are really acquainted with the original, will acknowlege it to be at least a tolerable resemblance.

It would be ungrateful in the highest degree to close this preface, without acknowleging the very great obligations which the author has to Mr. Garrick. Every attention, which either as a manager, or as a man, he could give to the interest of the following play, he has bestowed with the most generous alacrity; but universally admired as he is at present, his intrinsic value will not be known, till his loss is deplored; and the public have great reason to wish, that this may be a very distant event in the annals of the theatre. The Epilogue sufficiently marks the masterly hand from which it originated; so does the comic commencement of the Prologue, and the elegant writer of the graver part, is a character of distinguished eminence in the literary republic.

It has been remarked with great justice, that few new pieces were ever better performed than The School for Wives. Mr. King, that highly-deserving
favourite of the town, was every thing the author could possibly wish in General Savage. Mr. Reddish acquired a very considerable share of merited reputation in Belville. Mr. Moody is unequalled in his Irishmen. Mr. Palmer, from his manner of supporting Leeson, was entitled to a much better part: And Mr. Weston in Torington was admirable. Miss Younge, in Mrs. Belville, extorted applause from the coldest auditor. Her tenderness—her force—her pathos, were the true effusions of genius, and proved that she has no superior where the feelings are to be interested. With respect to Mrs. Abington, enough can never be said. The elegance, the vivacity, the critical nicety with which she went through Miss Walsingham, is only to be guessed at, by those who are familiar with the performance of that exquisite actress. Her Epilogue was delivered with an animation not to be conceived, and manifested the strict propriety, with which she is called the first priestess of the Comic Muse in this country.

THE SCHOOL FOR WIVES, BEING A COMEDY IN WHICH THE LADIES ARE PARTICULARLY INTERESTED, IT SHOULD BE ADDRESS'D TO THE FIRST ORNAMENT OF THE SEX; AND IS THEREFORE INSCRIBED WITH THE HIGHEST ADMIRATION AND THE MOST PROFOUND REVERENCE, TO HER MAJESTY; NOT BECAUSE SHE IS THE GREATEST OF QUEENS, BUT BECAUSE IN THE MILDER, AND MORE ENDEARING RELATIONS OF LIFE, SHE IS THE BRIGHTEST PATTERN OF ALL THE FEMALE VIRTUES.

sp.l: NO coward he, who in this critick age,
Dares set his foot upon the dang'rous stage;
These boards, like Ice, your footing will betray,

l.hi: Who can tread sure upon a slipp'ry way?

sp.l: Yet some thro' five acts, slide with wond'rous skill,
Skim swift along, turn, stop, or wind at will!
Some tumble, and get up; some rise no more;
While cruel criticks watch them on the shore,
And at each stumble make a hellish roar!
A wise Philosopher, hath truly noted,
(His name I have forgot, tho' often quoted,)
That fine-spun spirits from the slightest cause,
Draw to themselves affliction, or applause:
So fares it with our Bard.—Last week he meets
Some hawkers, roaring up and down the streets,
Lives, characters, behaviour, parentage,
Of some who lately left the mortal stage!
His ears so caught the sound, and work'd his mind,
He thought his own name floated in the wind;
As thus—"Here is a faithful, true relation,
"Of the birth, parentage, and education,
"Last dying speech, confession, character,
"Of the unhappy malefacterer,
"And comick poet, Thomas Addle Brain!
"Who suffer'd Monday last at Drury Lane;
"All for the price of half-penny a piece;"
Still in his ears these horrid sounds encrease!
Try'd and condemn'd, half executed too;
There stands the culprit; 'till repriev'd by you.

sp.speaker: Miss YOUNGE.
sp.l: Pray give me leave—I've something now to say.

sp.speaker: Mr. KING.
sp.l: Is't at the School for Wives, you're taught this way?
The School for Husbands teaches to obey.

lg.l: It is a shame, good Sirs, that brother King,
To joke and laughter, should turn every thing.
Our frighted poet would have no denial,
But, begs me to say something on his trial:
The School for Wives, as it to us belongs,
Should for our use be guarded with our tongues.
Ladies, prepare, arm well your brows and eyes,
From those your thunder, these your light'ning flies.
Should storms be rising in the Pit—look down,
And still the waves thus, fair ones, with a frown:
Or should the Galleries for war declare;
Look up—your eyes will carry twice as far.
The conclusion of the Prologue from this line is by another hand.Our Bard, to noble triumphs points your way,
Bids you in moral principles be gay;
Something he'd alter in your education,
Something which hurting you, would hurt a nation:
Ingenuous natures wish you to reclaim?
By smiling virtue you'll insure your aim:
That gilds with bliss the matrimonial hours,
And blends her laurels with the sweetest flowers.
Ye married fair! deign to attend our school,
And without usurpation learn to rule:
Soon will he cease mean objects to pursue,
In conscience wretched till he lives to you;
Your charms will reformation's pain beguile,
And vice receive a stab from every smile.

sp.l: CAN it be thought, ye wives! this scribbling fool,
Will draw you here, by calling you to School?
Does not he know, poor soul! to be directed,
Is what you hate, and more to be corrected!
Long have these walls to public fame been known,
An ancient College to instruct the town!
We've Schools for Rakes, for Fathers, Lovers, Wives,
For naughty girls and boys, to mend their lives:
Where some to yawn, some round about to look,
Some to be seen, few come to mind their book:
Some with high wit and humour hither run,
To sweat the masters—and they call it fun.
Some modish sparks, true stoicks, and high bred,
Come, but ne'er know what's done, or sung, or said;
Should the whole herd of criticks round them roar,
And with one voice cry out, encore! encore!
Or louder yet, off, off; no more! no more!
Should Pit, Box, Gall'ry with convulsions shake,
Still are they half asleep, nor t'other half awake;
O, ladies fair! are these fit men to wed?
Such husbands, half, had better be quite dead.
But, to return,—vain men, throughout the nation,
Boast, they alone, have College education:
Are not we qualify'd to take degrees?
We've caps, and gowns, nay bands too, if you please,
Cornelly's, and Almack's, our Universities!
Young female students rise, if girls of parts,
From under graduates,—mistresses of arts!
The bashful spinsters, turn important spouses,
Strive to be masters, and the heads of houses!
Will any of you here, blest with a wife,
Dispute the fact,—you dare not for your life.
Pray tell me truly, criticks, and be free,
Do you this night prefer the Wife to me?
Shall Mrs. Belville give the Play a name?
What are her merits? a cold, smiling dame,
While I, a salamander, liv'd in flame!
Press'd by three lovers!—'twas indeed provoking!
Ladies, upon my word, it was no joking.
Can you from mortal woman more require,
Than save her fingers, and yet play with fire?
The risks I run, the partial hard upbraids;
Wives won't be taught,—be it the School for Maids.

div3.stage: Enter Captain SAVAGE, and Miss WALSINGHAM.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: HA! ha! ha! Well, Miss Walsingham, this fury is going; what a noble peal she has rung in Belville's ears!

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Did she see you, Captain Savage?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: No, I took care of that; for tho' she is'n't married to my father, she has ten times the influence of a wife, and might injure me not a little with him, if I didn't support her side of the question.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: It was a pleasant conceit of Mr. Belville, to insinuate the poor woman was disordered in her senses!—

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: And did you observe how the termagant's violence of temper, supported the probability of the charge?

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Yes, she became almost frantic in reality, when she found herself treated like a madwoman.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Belville's affected surprise too, was admirable!

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Yes, the hypocritical composure of his countenance, and his counterfeit pity for the poor woman, were intolerable!

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: While that amiable creature, his wife, implicitly believed every syllable he said—

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: And felt nothing but pity for the accuser, instead of paying the least regard to the accusation. But pray, is it really under a pretence of getting the girl upon the stage, that Belville has taken away Mrs. Tempest's neice from the people she boarded with?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: It is: Belville, ever on the look out for fresh objects, met her in those primitive regions of purity, the Green-Boxes; where, discovering that she was passionately desirous of becoming an actress, he improved his acquaintance with her, in the fictitious character of an Irish manager, and she eloped last night, to be, as she imagines, the heroine of a Dublin theatre.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: So, then, as he has kept his real name artfully conceal'd, Mrs. Tempest can at most but suspect him of Miss Leeson's seduction.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Of no more; and this, only, from the description of the people who saw him in company with her at the play; but, I wish the affair may not have a serious conclusion; for she has a brother, a very spirited young fellow, who is a council in the Temple, and who will certainly call Belville to an account, the moment he hears of it.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: And what will become of the poor creature after he has deserted her?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: You know that Belville is generous to profusion, and has a thousand good qualities to counter-balance this single fault of gallantry, which contaminates his character.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: You men! you men!—You are such wretches that there's no having a moment's satisfaction with you! and what's still more provoking, there's no having a moment's satisfaction without you!

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Nay, don't think us all alike.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: I'll endeavour to deceive myself; for it is but a poor argument of your sincerity, to be the confidant of another's falsehood.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Nay, no more of this, my love; no people live happier than Belville and his wife; nor is there a man in England, notwithstanding all his levity, who considers his wife with a warmer degree of affection: if you have a friendship therefore, for her, let her continue in an error, so necessary to her repose, and give no hint, whatever, of his gallantries to any body.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: If I had no pleasure in obliging you, I have too much regard for Mrs. Belville, not to follow your advice; but you need not enjoin me so strongly on the subject, when you know I can keep a secret.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: You are all goodness; and the prudence with which you have conceal'd our private engagements, has eternally oblig'd me; had you trusted the secret even to Mrs. Belville, it wou'dn't have been safe; she wou'd have told her husband, and he is such a rattleskul, that, notwithstanding all his regard for me, he wou'd have mention'd it in some moment of levity, and sent it in a course of circulation to my father.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p:
The peculiarity of your father's temper, join'd to my want of fortune, made it necessary for me to keep our engagements inviolably secret; there is no merit, therefore, either in my prudence, or in my labouring assiduously to cultivate the good opinion of the General; since both were so ecessary
to my own happiness; don't despise me for this acknowledgement now.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Bewitching softness!—But your goodness, I flatter myself, will be speedily rewarded; you are now such a favourite with him, that he is eternally talking of you; and I really fancy he means to propose you to me himself: for, last night, in a few minutes after he had declared you would make the best wife in the world, he seriously ask'd me if I had any aversion to matrimony?

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Why, that was a very great concession indeed, as he seldom stoops to consult any body's inclinations.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: So it was, I assure you; for, in the army, being used to nothing but command and obedience, he removes the discipline of the parade into his family, and no more expects his orders shou'd be disputed, in matters of a domestic nature, than if they were deliver'd at the head of his regiment.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: And yet, Mrs. Tempest, who you say is as much a storm in her nature as her name, is disputing them eternally.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Well, Miss Walsingham, hav'n't we had a pretty morning's visitor?

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Really, I think so; and I have been asking Capt. Savage, how long the lady has been disordered in her senses?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Why will they let the poor woman abroad, without some body to take care of her?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: O, she has her lucid intervals.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: I declare I shall be as angry with you as I am with Belville. (aside to the Captain.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: You can't think how sensibly she spoke at first.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
I should have had no conception of her madness,
if she hadn't brought so preposterous a charge against me.

sp.speaker: SER.
sp.p: Lady Rachel Mildew, Madam, sends her compliments, and if you are not particularly engaged, will do herself the pleasure of waiting upon you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Our compliments, and we shall be glad to see her Ladyship. Ex. Servant.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I wonder if Lady Rachel knows that Torrington came to town last night from Bath!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: I hope he has found benefit by the waters, for he is one of the best creatures existing; he's a downright parson Adams, in good nature and simplicity.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Lady Rachel will be quite happy at his return, and it would be a laughable affair, if a match could be brought about between the old maid and the old bachelor.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Mr. Torrington is too much taken up at Westminster-Hall, to think of paying his devoirs to the ladies; and too plain a speaker, I fancy, to be agreeable to Lady Rachel.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: You mistake the matter widely; she is deeply smitten with him; but honest Torrington is utterly unconscious of his conquest, and modestly thinks that he has not a single attraction for any woman in the universe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Yet my poor aunt speaks sufficiently plain, in all conscience, to give him a different opinion of himself.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Yes, and puts her charms into such repair, whenever she expects to meet him, that her cheeks look for all the world like a rasberry ice upon a ground of custard.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p:
I thought Apollo was the only god of Lady
Rachel's idolatary, and that in her passion for poetry she had taken leave of all the less elevated affections.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: O, you mistake again; the poets are eternally in love, and can by no means be calculated to describe the imaginary passions, without being very susceptible of the real ones.

sp.speaker: SER.
sp.p: The man, Madam, from Tavistock-street, has brought home the dresses for the masquerade, and desires to know if there are any commands for him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: O, bid him stay till we see the dresses.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: They are only Dominos.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I am glad of that; for characters are as difficult to be supported at the masquerade, as they are in real life. The last time I was at the Pantheon, a vestal virgin invited me to sup with her, and swore that her pocket had been pick'd by a Justice of peace.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Nay, that was not so bad, as the Hamlet's Ghost that box'd with Henry the Eighth, and afterwards danc'd a hornpipe to the tune of Nancy Dawson. Ha! ha! ha!—We follow you, Mrs. Belville. Exeunt.

head.stage: Scene changes to LEESON's Chambers in the Temple:

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Where is this clerk of mine? Connolly!

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: (behind) Here, Sir!

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Have you copied the marriage settlement, as I corrected it?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: (Enters with pistols) Ay, honey, an hour ago.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: What, you have been trying those pistols?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: By my soul, I have been firing them this half hour, without once being able to make them go off.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: They are plaguy dirty.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: In troth, so they are: I strove to brighten them up a little, but some misfortune attends every thing I do, for the more I clane them, the dirtier they are, honey.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: You have had some of our usual daily visitors for money, I suppose?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: You may say that; and three or four of them are now hanging about the door, that I wish handsomely hang'd any where else, for bodering us.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: No joking, Connolly! my present situation is a very disagreeable one.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Faith, and so it is; but who makes it disareeable? your Aunt Tempest would let you have as much money as you please, but you won't condescend to be acquainted with her, though people in this country can be very intimate friends, without seeing one anothers faces for seven years.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Do you think me base enough to receive a favour from a woman, who has disgraced her family, and stoops to be a kept mistress? you see, my sister is already ruin'd by a connection with her.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Ah, Sir, a good guinea isn't the worse for coming through a bad hand; if it was, what would become of us lawyers? and by my soul, many a high head in London would, at this minute, be very low, if they hadn't recieved favours even from much worse people than kept mistresses.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Others, Connolly, may prostitute their honour, as they please; mine is my chief possession, and I must take particular care of it.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p:
Honour, to be sure, is a very fine thing, Sir; but I don't see how it is to be taken care of, without a little money; your honour, to my knowledge, has'n't been in your own possession these two
years, and the devil a crum can you honestly swear by, till you get it out of the hands of your creditors.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: I have given you a licence to talk, Connolly, because I know you faithful; but I hav'n't given you a liberty to sport with my misfortunes.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: You know I'd die to serve you, Sir; but of what use is your giving me leave to spake, if you oblige me to hould my tongue? 'tis out of pure love and affection that I put you in mind of your misfortunes.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Well, Connolly, a few days will, in all probability, enable me to redeem my honour, and to reward your fidelity; the lovely Emily, you know, has half consented to embrace the first opportunity of flying with me to Scotland, and the paltry trifles I owe, will not be miss'd in her Fortune.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: But, dear Sir, consider you are going to fight a duel this very evening, and if you shou'd be kilt, I fancy you will find it a little difficult, to run away afterwards with the lovely Emily.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: If I fall, there will be an end to my misfortunes.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: But surely it will not be quite genteel, to go out of the world without paying your debts.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: But how shall I stay in the world, Connolly, without punishing Belville for ruining my sister?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: O, the devil fly away with this honour; an ounce of common sense, is worth a whole ship load of it, if we must prefer a bullet or a halter, to a fine young lady and a great fortune.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: We'll talk no more on the subject at present. Take this letter to Mr. Belville; deliver it into his own hand, be sure; and bring me an answer: make haste; for I shall not stir out till you come back.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: By my soul, I wish you may be able to stir out then, honey.—O, but that's true!

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p:
Why, Sir, the gentleman I last liv'd clerk
with, died lately and left me a legacy of twenty guineas—

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: What! is Mr. Stanley dead?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Faith, his friends have behav'd very unkindly if he is not, for they have buried him these six weeks.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: And what then?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Why, Sir, I received my little legacy this morning, and if you'd be so good as to keep it for me, I'd be much oblig'd to you.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Connolly, I understand you, but I am already shamefully in your debt: you've had no money from me this age.—

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: O Sir, that does not signify; if you are not kilt in this damn'd duel, you'll be able enough to pay me: if you are, I shan't want it.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Why so, my poor fellow?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Because, tho' I am but your clerk, and tho' I think fighting the most foolish thing upon earth, I'm as much a gintleman as yourself, and have as much right to commit a murder in the way of duelling.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: And what then? You have no quarrel with Mr. Belville?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: I shall have a damn'd quarrel with him tho' if you are kilt: your death shall be reveng'd, depend upon it, so let that content you.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: My dear Connolly, I hope I shan't want such a proof of your affection.—How he distresses me!

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: You will want a second, I suppose, in this affair: I stood second to my own brother, in the Fifteen Acres, and tho' that has made me detest the very thought of duelling ever since; yet if you want a friend, I'll attend you to the field of death with a great deal of satisfaction.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p:
I thank you, Connolly, but I think it extremely wrong in any man who has a quarrel, to expose
his friend to difficulties; we shou'dn't seek for redress, if we are not equal to the task of fighting our own battles; and I choose you particularly, to carry my letter because, you may be supposed ignorant of the contents, and thought to be acting only in the ordinary course of your business.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Say no more about it, honey; I will be back with you presently. (going, returns.) I put the twenty guineas in your pocket, before you were up, Sir; and I don't believe you'd look for such a thing there, if I wasn't to tell you of it. Exit.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: This faithful, noble-hearted creature!— but let me fly from thought; the business I have to execute, will not bear the test of reflection. Exit.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: As this is a challenge, I shou'dn't go without a sword; come down, little tickle-pitcher. (Takes a sword.) Some people may think me very conceited now; but as the dirtiest black legs in town can wear one without being stared at, I don't think it can suffer any disgrace by the side of an honest man.

head.stage: SCENE changes to an Apartment at BELVILLE'S.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p:
How strangely this affair of Mrs. Tempest hangs upon my spirits, tho' I have every reason, from the tenderness, the politeness, and the generosity of Mr. Belville, as well as from the woman's behaviour, to believe the whole charge the result of a disturb'd imagination.—Yet suppose it should be actually true:—heigho!—well, suppose it shou'd;—I wou'd endeavour—I think I wou'd endeavour to keep my temper:—a frowning face never recovered a heart that was not to be fix'd with a smiling one:—but women, in general, forget this grand article of the matrimonial
creed entirely; the dignity of insulted virtue obliges them to play the fool, whenever their Corydons play the libertine;—and poh! they must pull down the house about the traitor's ears, tho' they are themselves to be crush'd in pieces by the ruins.

sp.speaker: SER.
sp.p: Lady Rachel Mildew, madam. Exit Ser.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: My dear, how have you done since the little eternity of my last seeing you. Mr. Torrington is come to town, I hear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: He is, and must be greatly flattered to find that your Ladyship has made him the hero of your new comedy.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Yes, I have drawn him as he is, an honest practitioner of the law; which is I fancy no very common character—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: And it must be a vast acquisition to the Theatre.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Yet the managers of both houses have refused my play; have refused it peremptorily! tho' I offer'd to make them a present of it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: That's very surprizing, when you offer'd to make them a present of it.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: They alledge that the audiences are tired of crying at comedies; and insist that my Despairing Shepherdess is absolutely too dismal for representation.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: What, tho' you have introduced a lawyer in a new light?

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Yes, and have a boarding-school romp, that slaps her mother's face, and throws a bason of scalding water at her governess.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Why, surely, these are capital jokes!

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: But the managers can't find them out.—However, I am determined to bring it out somewhere; and I have discover'd such a treasure for my boarding-school romp, as exceeds the most sanguine expectation of criticism.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: How fortunate!

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Goings to Mrs. Le Blond, my millener's, this morning, to see some contraband silks, (for you know there's a foreign minister just arriv'd) I heard a loud voice rehearsing Juliet, from the dining-room; and upon enquiry found that it was a country girl, just elop'd from her friends in town, to go upon the stage with an Irish manager.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Ten to one, the strange woman's neice, who has been here this morning. aside.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Mrs. Le Blond has some doubts about the manager it seems, though she hasn't seen him yet, because the apartments are very expensive, and were taken by a fine gentleman out of livery.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: What am I to think of this?—Pray, Lady Rachel, as you have convers'd with this young actress, I suppose you could procure me a sight of her.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: This moment if you will, I am very intimate with her already; but pray keep the matter a secret from your husband, for he is so witty, you know, upon my passion for the drama, that I shall be teized to death by him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: O, you may be very sure that your secret is safe, for I have a most particular reason to keep it from Mr. Belville; but he is coming this way with Captain Savage, let us at present avoid him. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p:
You are a very strange man, Belville; you are for ever tremblingly solicitous about the happiness
of your wife, yet for ever endangering it by your passion for variety.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Why, there is certainly a contradiction between my principles and my practice; but, if ever you marry, you'll be able to reconcile it perfectly. Possession, Savage! O, possession, is a miserable whetter of the appetite in love! and I own myself so sad a fellow, that though I wou'dn't exchange Mrs. Belville's mind for any woman's upon earth, there is scarcely a woman's person upon earth, which is not to me a stronger object of attraction.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Then perhaps in a little time you'll be weary of Miss Leeson?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: To be sure I shall; though to own the truth, I have not yet carried my point conclusively with the little monkey.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Why how the plague has she escap'd a moment in your hands?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: By a mere accident.—She came to the lodgings, which my man Spruce prepar'd for her, rather unexpectedly last night, so that I happened to be engaged particularly in another quarter—you understand me—and the damn'd aunt found me so much employment all the morning, that I could only send a message by Spruce, promising to call upon her the first moment I had to spare in the course of the day.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: And so your are previously satisfied that you shall be tired of her.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Tir'd of her?—Why I am at this moment in pursuit of fresh game, against the hour of satiety:—Game that you know to be exquisite! and I fancy I shall bring it down, though it is closely guarded by a deal of that pride, which passes for virtue with the generallity of your mighty good people.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Indeed! and may a body know this wonder?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: You are to be trusted with any thing, for you are the closest fellow I ever knew, and the rack itself would hardly make you discover one of your own secrets to any body—what do you think of Miss Walsingham?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Miss Walsingham?—Death and the devil!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Miss Walsingham:

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Why surely she has not received your addresses with any degree of approbation?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: With every degree of approbation I cou'd expect.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: She has?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Ay: Why this news surprises you?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: It does indeed!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I can't help laughing to think what a happy dog Miss Walsingham's husband is likely to be!

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: A very happy dog, truly!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: She's a delicious girl, is'n't she, Savage?— but she'll require a little more trouble;—for a fine woman, like a fortified town, to speak in your father's language, demands a regular siege; and we must even allow her the honours of war, to magnify the greatness of our own victory.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Well, it amazes me how you gay fellows ever have the presumption to attack a woman of principle; Miss Walsingham has no apparent levity of any kind about her.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: No; but she continued in my house, after I had whispered my passion in her ear, and gave me a second opportunity of addressing her improperly; what greater encouragement cou'd I desire?
Well, Spruce, what are your commands?

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: My Lady is just gone out with Lady Rachel, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I understand you.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: I believe you do. (Aside.) Exit.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: What is the English of these significant looks between Spruce and you?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Only that Miss Walsingham is left alone, and that I have now an opportunity of entertaining her; you must excuse me, Savage; you must upon my soul; but not a word of this affair to any body; because when I shake her off my hands, there may be fools enough to think of her, upon terms of honourable matrimony. Exit

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: So, here's a discovery! a precious discovery! and while I have been racking my imagination, and sacrificing my interest, to promote the happiness of this woman, she has been listening to the addresses of another; to the addresses of a married man! the husband of her friend, and the immediate friend of her intended husband!—By Belville's own account, however, she has not yet proceeded to any criminal lengths—But why did she keep the affair a secret from me? or why did she continue in his house after a repeated declaration of his unwarrantable attachment?—What's to be done?—If I open my engagement with her to Belville, I am sure he will instantly desist;—but then her honour is left in a state extremely questionable—It shall be still concealed— While it remains unknown, Belville will himself tell me every thing;—and doubt, upon an occasion of this nature, is infinitely more insupportable than the downright falsehood of the woman whom we love.

div3.trailer: The END of the FIRST ACT.

head.stage: an Apartment in General SAVAGE's House.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: ZOUNDS! Torrington, give me quarter, when I surrender up my sword: I own that for these twenty years, I have been suffering all the inconveniences of marriage, without tasting any one of its comforts, and rejoicing in an imaginary freedom, while I was really grovelling in chains.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: In the dirtiest chains upon earth;—yet you wou'dn't be convinc'd, but laugh'd at all your married acquaintance as slaves, when not one of them put up with half so much from the worst wife, as you were oblig'd to crouch under, from a kept mistress.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: 'Tis too true. But, you know, she sacrificed much for me;—you know that she was the widow of a colonel, and refus'd two very advantageous matches on my account.—

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: If she was the widow of a judge, and had refused a high chancellor, she was still a devil incarnate, and you were of course a madman to live with her.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: You don't remember her care of me when I have been sick.—

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: I recollect, however, her usage of you in health, and you may easily find a tenderer nurse, when you are bound over by the gout or the rheumatism.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Well, well, I agree with you that she is a devil incarnate; but I am this day determin'd to part with her for ever.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Not you indeed.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: What, don't I know my own mind?

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Not you indeed, when she is in the question; with every body else, your resolution is as unalterable as a determination in the house of peers; but Mrs. Tempest is your fate, and she reverses your decrees with as little difficulty as a fraudulent debtor now-a-days procures his certificate under a commission of bankruptcy.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Well if, like the Roman Fabius, I conquer by delay, in the end, there will be no great reason to find fault with my generalship. The proposal of parting now comes from herself.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: O, you darn't make it for the life of you.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: You must know that this morning we had a smart cannonnading on Belville's account, and she threatens, as I told you before, to quit my house if I don't challenge him for taking away her neice.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: That fellow is the very devil among the women, and yet there isn't a man in England fonder of his wife.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Poh, if the young minx hadn't surrender'd to him, she would have capitulated to somebody else, and I shall at this time be doubly obliged to him, if he is any ways instrumentall in getting the aunt off my hands.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Why at this time?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Because to shew you how fix'd my resolution is to be a keeper no longer, I mean to marry immediately.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: And can't you avoid being press'd to death, like a felon who refuses to plead, without incurring a sentence of perpetual imprisonment?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p:
I fancy you would yourself have no objection
to a perpetual imprisonment in the arms of Miss Walsingham.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: But have you any reason to think that upon examination in a case of love, she would give a favourable reply to your interrogatories?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: The greatest—do you think I'd hazard such an engagement without being perfectly sure of my ground? Notwithstanding my present connection won't suffer me to see a modest woman at my own house—She always treats me with particular attention whenever I visit at Belville's, or meet her any where else—If fifty young fellows are present, she directs all her assiduities to the old soldier, and my son has a thousand times told me that she professes the highest opinion of my understanding.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: And truly you give a notable proof of your understanding, in thinking of a woman almost young enough to be your grand-daughter.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Nothing like an experienc'd chief to command in any garrison.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Recollect the state of your present citadel.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Well, if I am blown up by my own mine, I shall be the only sufferer—There's another thing I want to talk of, I am going to marry my son to Miss Moreland.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Miss Moreland!—

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Belville's sister.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: O, ay, I remember that Moreland had got a good estate to assume the name of Belville.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I have'nt yet mention'd the matter to my son, but I settled the affair with the girl's mother yesterday, and she only waits to communicate it to Belville, who is her oracle, you know.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: And are you sure the captain will like her?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I am not so unreasonable as to insist upon his liking her, I shall only insist upon his marrying her.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: What, whether he likes her or not?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: When I issue my orders, I expect them to be obey'd; and don't look for an examination into their propriety.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: What a delightful thing it must be to live under a military government, where a man is not to be troubled with the exercise of his understanding.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Miss Moreland has thirty thousand pounds— That's a large sum of ammunition money.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Ay, but a marriage merely on the score of fortune, is only gilding the death-warrant sent down for the execution of a prisoner. However as I know your obstinate attachment to what you once resolve, I shan't pretend to argue with you; where are the papers which you want me to consider?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: They are in my library—File off with me to the next room and they shall be laid before you— But first I'll order the chariot, for the moment I have your opinion, I purpose to sit down regularly before Miss Walsingham—who waits there?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Is Mrs. Tempest at home?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, just come in, and just going out again.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Very well; order the chariot to be got ready.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Sir, one of the pannels was broke last night at the Opera-house.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Sir, I didn't call to have the pleasure of your conversation, but to have obedience paid to my orders.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Go order the chariot, you blockhead.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: With the broken pannel, Sir.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Yes, you rascal, if both pannels were broke, and the back shattered to pieces.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: The coachman thinks that one of the wheels is damag'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p:
Don't attempt to reason, you dog, but execute
your orders.—Bring the chariot without the wheels—if you can't bring it with them.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Ay bring it, if you reduce it to a sledge, and let your master look like a malefactor for high treason, on his journey to Tyburn.

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEMP.
sp.p: General Savage, is the house to be for ever a scene of noise with your domineering?— The chariot shan't be brought—it won't be fit for use 'till it is repaired—and John, shall drive it this very minute to the coach-makers.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Nay, my dear, if it isn't fit for use that's another thing.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Here's the experienced chief that's fit to command in any garrison. (aside.)

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Go order me the coach then. to the Ser.

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEMP.
sp.p: You can't have the coach.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: And why so, my love.

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEMP.
sp.p: Because I want it for myself.—Robert, get a hack for your master—tho' indeed I don't see what business he has out of the house.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: When you issue your orders, you expect them to be obey'd, and don't look for an examination into their propriety.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: The fury!—this has steel'd me against her for ever, and nothing on earth can now prevent me from drumming her out immediately.

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEMP.
sp.p: (behind) An unreasonable old fool— But I'll make him know who governs this house!

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Zounds! here she comes again; she has been lying in ambuscade, I suppose, and has over heard us.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: What if she has? you are steel'd against her for ever.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p:
No, she's not coming—she's going down
stairs;—and now, dear Torrington, you must be as silent as a sentinel on an out-post about this affair. If that virago was to hear a syllable of it, she might perhaps attack Miss Walsingham in her very camp, and defeat my whole plan of operations.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: I thought you were determin'd to drum her out immediately. Exeunt.

div3.stage: Enter Miss WALSINGHAM, followed by BELVILLE.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: I beg, Sir, that you will insult me no longer with solicitations of this nature—Give me proofs of your sincerity indeed! What proofs of sincerity can your situation admit of, if I could be even weak enough to think of you with partiality at all?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: If our affections, Madam, were under the government of our reason, circumstanced as I am, this unhappy bosom wouldn't be torn by passion for Miss Walsingham.—Had I been bless'd with your acquaintance, before I saw Mrs. Belville, my hand as well as my heart, wou'd have been humbly offer'd to your acceptance—fate, however, has ordered it otherwise, and it is cruel to reproach me with that situation as a crime, which ought to be pitied as my greatest misfortune.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: He's actually forcing tears into his eyes.—However, I'll mortify him severely. (aside.)

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: But such proofs of sincerity as my situation can admit of, you shall yourself command, as my only business in existence is to adore you.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: His only business in existence to adore me. (aside.)

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
Prostrate at your feet, my dearest Miss Walsingham (kneeling) behold a heart eternally devoted to your service.—You have too much good sense, Madam, to be the slave of custom, and too much humanity not to pity the wretchedness you have
caused.—Only, therefore, say that you commiserate my sufferings—I'll ask no more—and surely that may be said, without any injury to your purity, to snatch even an enemy from distraction—where's my handkerchief? aside.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Now to answer in his own way, and to make him ridiculous to himself— (aside.) If I thought, if I could think (affecting to weep) that these protestations were real.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: How can you, Madam, be so unjust to your own merit? how can you be so cruelly doubtful of my solemn asseverations?—Here I again kneel, and swear eternal love!

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: I don't know what to say—but there is one proof— (affecting to weep.)

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Name it, my angel, this moment, and make me the happiest of mankind!

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Swear to be mine for ever.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I have sworn it a thousand times, my charmer; and I will swear it to the last moment of my life.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Why then—but don't look at me I beseech you—I don't know how to speak it—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: The delicious emotion—do not check the generous tide of tenderness that fills me with such extasy.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: You'll despise me for this weakness.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: This weakness—this generosity which will demand my everlasting gratitude.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: I am a fool—but there is a kind of fatality in this affair—and I do consent to go off with you.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Eternal blessings on your condescension.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: You are irresistible, and I am ready to fly with you to any part of the world.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
Fly to any part of the world indeed—you shall fly by yourself then; (aside.) You are the
most lovely, the most tender creature in the world, and thus again let me thank you: O, Miss Walsingham, I cannot express how happy you've made me!—But where's the necessity of our leaving England?—

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: I thought he wouldn't like to go abroad— (aside.) That I may possess the pleasure of your company unrival'd.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I must cure her of this taste for travelling—

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: You don't answer, Mr. Belville?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Why I was turning the consequence of your proposal in my thoughts, as going off—going off— you know.—

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Why going off, you know, is going off— And what objections can you have to going off?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Why going off, will subject you at a certainty, to the slander of the world; whereas by staying at home, we may not only have numberless opportunities of meeting, but at the same time prevent suspicion it self, from ever breathing on your reputation.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: I didn't dream of your starting any difficulties, Sir.—Just now I was dearer to you than all the world.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: And so you are, by heav'n!

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Why won't you sacrifice the world then at once to obtain me?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Surely, my dearest life, you must know the necessity, which every man of honour is under of keeping up his character?

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p:
So, here's this fellow swearing to ten thousand lies, and yet talking very gravely about his honour and his character. (aside.) Why, to be sure in these days, Mr. Belville, the instances of conjugal infidelity are so very scarce, and men of fashion are so remarkable for a tender attachment to their wives, that I don't wonder at your circumspection—But do
you think I can stoop to accept you by halves, or admit of any partnership in your heart?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: O you must do more than that, if you have any thing to say to me. (aside.) Surely, Madam, when you know my whole soul unalterably your own, you will permit me to preserve those appearances with the world, which are indispensibly requisite—Mrs. Belville is a most excellent woman, however it may be my fortune to be devoted to another—Her happiness, besides, constitutes a principal part of my felicity, and if I was publicly to forsake her, I should be hunted as a monster from society.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Then, I suppose, it is by way of promoting Mrs. Belville's repose, Sir, that you make love to other women; and by way of shewing the nicety of your honour, that you attempt the purity of such as your own roof, peculiarly, intitles to protection. For the honour intended to me—thus low to the ground, I thank you, Mr. Belville.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Laugh'd at, by all the stings of mortification▪

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Good bye.—Don't let this accident mortify your vanity too much;—but take care, the next time you vow everlasting love, that the object is neither tender enough to sob—sob—at your distress; nor provoking enough to make a proposal of leaving England.—How greatly a little common sense can lower these fellows of extraordinary impudence?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
(alone.) So then, I am fairly taken in, and she has been only diverting herself with me all this time:— however, lady fair, I may chance to have the laugh in a little time on my side; for if you can sport in this manner about the flame, I think it must in the run lay hold of your wings:—what shall I do in this affair?—she sees the matter in its true light, and there's no good to be expected from thumping of bosoms, or squeezing white handkerchiefs;—no these
won't do with women of sense, and in a short time, they'll be ridiculous to the very babies of a boarding-school.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Well, Belville, what news? You have had a fresh opportunity with Miss Walsingham.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Why, faith, Savage, I've had a most extraordinary scene with her, and yet have but little reason to brag of my good fortune, tho' she offer'd in express terms to run away with me.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Prith'ee explain yourself, man; she cou'dn't surely be so shameless!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: O, her offering to run away with me, was by no means the worst part of the affair.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: No, then it must be damn'd bad indeed! but prith'ee, hurry to an explanation.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Why then, the worst part of the affair is, that she was laughing at me the whole time; and made this proposal of an elopement, with no other view, than to shew me in strong colours to myself, as a very dirty fellow to the best wife in England.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: I am easy. aside.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: Sir, there is an Irish gentleman below with a letter for you, who will deliver it to nobody but yourself.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Shew him up then.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: It may be on business Belville, I'll take my leave of you.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: O, by no means; I can have no business which I desire to keep from you, tho' you are the arrant'st miser of your confidence upon earth, and wou'd rather trust your life in any body's hands, than even a paltry amour with the apprentice of a millener.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Gintlemin, your most obedient; pray which of you is Mr. Belville?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: My name is Belville, at your service, Sir.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: I have a little bit of a letter for you, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
SIR,
The people where Miss Leeson lately lodg'd, asserting positively that you have taken her away in a fictitious character, the brother of that unhappy girl, thinks himself oblig'd to demand satisfaction, for the injury which you have done his family; tho' a stranger to your person, he is sufficiently acquainted with your reputation for spirit, and shall, therefore, make no doubt of seeing you with a case of pistols, near the Ring in Hyde Park, at eight o'clock this evening, to answer the claims of
George Leeson.
To Craggs Belville, Esq.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Eight o'clock in the evening! 'tis a strange time!

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Why so, honey? A fine evening is as good a time for a bad action as a fine morning; and if a man of sense can be such a fool as to fight a duel, he shou'd never sleep upon the matter, for the more he thinks of it, the more he must feel himself asham'd of his resolution.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: A pretty letter!

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: O yes, an invitation to a brace of bullets is a very pretty thing.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: For a challenge, however, 'tis very civilly written!

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Faith, if it was written to me, I shou'dn't be very fond of such civility; I wonder he doesn't sign himself, your most obedient servant.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: I told you Leeson's character, and what wou'd become of this damn'd business; but your affairs—are they settled, Belville?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: O they are always settled—for as this is a country where people occasionally die, I take constant care to be prepared for contingencies.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Occasionally die!—I'll be very much oblig'd to you; Sir, if you tell me the country where people do not die? for I'll immediately go and end my days there.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: CON,
sp.p: Faith, you may laugh gintlemin, but tho' I am a foolish Irishman, and come about a foolish piece of business, I'd prefer a snug birth in this world, bad as it is, to the finest coffin in all Christendom.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I am surpris'd, Sir, that thinking in this manner, you would be the bearer of a challenge.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: And well you may, Sir.—But we must often take a pleasure in serving our friends, by doing things that are very disagreeable to us.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Then you think Mr. Leeson much to blame, perhaps, for hazarding his life where he can by no means repair the honour of his sister.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Indeed and I do—But I shall think this gintleman, begging his pardon, much more to blame for meeting him:

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: And why so, Sir—You woudn't have me disappoint your friend?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Faith, and that I wou'd—He, poor lad, may have some reason at present to be tir'd of the world, but you have a fine estate, a fine wife, a fine parcel of children.—In short, honey, you have every thing to make you fond of living, and the devil burn me, was I in your case, if I'd stake my own happiness against the misery of any man.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
I am very much oblig'd to your advice, Sir, tho' on the present occasion I cannot adopt it; be so
good as to present my compliments to your friend, and tell him I shall certainly do myself the honour of attending his appointment.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Why then upon my soul I am very sorry for it.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: 'Tis not very customary, Sir, with gentlemen of Ireland to oppose an affair of honour.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: They are like the gintlemin of England, Sir, they are brave to a fault; yet I hope to see the day that it will be infamous to draw the swords of either, against any body but the enemies of their country.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I am quite charmed with this honest Hibernian, and would almost fight a duel for the pleasure of his acquaintance.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Come, step with me a little, and let us consider, whether there may not be some method of accommodating this cursed business.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Poh! don't be uneasy upon my account; my character, with regard to affairs of this nature, is unhappily too well established, and you may be sure that I shan't fight with Leeson.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: No—you have injured him greatly?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: The very reason of all others why I should not cut his throat. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: What, the devil, this master of mine has got a a duel upon his hands! Zounds! I am sorry for that; he is a prince of a fellow! and a good subject must always love his prince, though he may now and then be a little out of humour with his actions.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Your hall-door standing open, Spruce, and none of your sentinels being on guard, I have surprised your camp thus far without resistance: Where is your master?

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: Just gone out with Captain Savage, Sir.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Is your lady at home?

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: No, Sir, but Miss Walsingham is at home; shall I inform her of your visit?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: There is no occasion to inform her of it, for here she is, Spruce. Exit Spruce.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: General Savage, your most humble servant.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: My dear Miss Walsingham, it is rather cruel that you should be left at home by yourself, and yet I am greatly rejoic'd to find you at present without company.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: I can't but think myself in the best company, when I have the honour of your conversation, General.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: You flatter me too much, Madam; yet I am come to talk to you on a serious affair, Miss Walsingham; an affair of importance to me and to yourself: Have you leisure to favour me with a short audience, if I beat a parley?

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Any thing of importance to you, Sir, is always sufficient to command my leisure.—'Tis as the Captain suspected. aside.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: You tremble, my lovely girl, but don't be alarmed; for though my business is of an important nature, I hope it won't be of a disagreeable one.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: And yet I am greatly agitated. aside.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Soldiers, Miss Walsingham, are said to be generally favour'd by the kind partiality of the ladies.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: The ladies are not without gratitude, Sir, to those who devote their lives peculiarly to the service of their country.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p:
Generously said, Madam: Then give me leave, without any masked battery, to ask, if the heart
of an honest soldier is a prize at all worth your acceptance.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Upon my word, Sir, there's no masked battery in this question.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I am as fond of a coup de main, Madam, in love, as in war, and hate the tedious method of sapping a town, when there is a possibility of entering sword in hand.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Why really, Sir, a woman may as well know her own mind, when she is first summoned by the trumpet of a lover, as when she undergoes all the tiresome formality of a siege. You see I have caught your own mode of conversing, General.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: And a very great compliment I consider it, Madam: But now that you have candidly confess'd an acquaintance with your own mind, answer me with that frankness for which every body admires you so much. Have you any objection to change the name of Walsingham?

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Why then frankly, General Savage I say, no.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Ten thousand thanks to you for this kind declaration.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: I hope you won't think it a forward one.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I'd sooner see my son run away in the day of battle;—I'd sooner think Lord Russell was bribed by Lewis the XIVth, and sooner villify the memory of Algernoon Sidney.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: How unjust it was ever to suppose the General a tyrannical father! aside.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: You have told me condescendingly, Miss Walsingham, that you have no objection to change your name, I have but one question more to ask.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Pray propose it.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Would the name of Savage be disagreeable to you?—Speak frankly again, my dear girl!

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Why then again I frankly say, no.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: You make me too happy; and though I shall readily own, that a proposal of this nature would come with more propriety from my son—

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: I am much better pleas'd that you make the proposal yourself, Sir.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: You are too good to me.—Torrington thought that I should meet with a repulse. aside.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Have you communicated this business to the Captain, Sir?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: No, my dear Madam, I did not think that at all necessary. I have always been attentive to the Captain's happiness, and I propose that he shall be married in a few days.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: What, whether I will or no?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: O you can have no objection.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: I must be consulted, however, about the day, General: but nothing in my power shall be wanting to make him happy.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Obliging loveliness!

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: You may imagine, that if I was not previously imprest in favour of your proposal, it wou'd not have met my concurrence so readily.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Then you own that I had a previous friend in the garrison.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: I don't blush to acknowledge it, when I consider the accomplishments of the object, Sir.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: O this is too much, Madam; the principle merit of the object is his passion for Miss Walsingham.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Don't say that, General, I beg of you, for I don't think there are many women in the kingdom, who could behold him with indifference.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Ah, you flattering, flattering angel!—and yet, by the memory of Marlborough, my lovely girl, it was the idea of a prepossession on your part, which encouraged me to hope for a favourable reception.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Then I must have been very indiscreet, for I labour'd to conceal that prepossession as much as possible.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: You cou'dn't conceal it from me! you cou'dn't conceal it from me!—The female heart is a field which I am thoroughly acquainted with, and which has more than once been a witness to my victories, Madam.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: I don't at all doubt your success with the ladies, General; but as we now understand one another so perfectly, you will give me leave to retire.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: One word, my dear creature, and no more; I shall wait upon you sometime to day, with Mr. Torrington, about the necessary settlements.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: You must do as you please, General, you are invincible in every thing.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: And if you please, we'll keep every thing a profound secret, 'till the articles are all settled, and the definitive treaty ready for execution.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: You may be sure, that delicacy will not suffer me to be communicate on the subject, Sir.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Then you leave every thing to my management.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: I can't trust a more noble negociator.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: The day's my own. (sings.) Britons, strike home! strike home! Revenge, &c. Exit singing.

div3.head: SCENE, Miss LEESON's Lodgings.
div3.stage: Enter Lady RACHEL MILDEW, Mrs. BELVILLE, and Miss LEESON.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: WELL, Mrs. Belville, I am extremely glad you agree with me, in opinion of this young lady's qualifications for the stage. Don't you think she'd play Miss Headstrong admirably in my comedy?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Yes, indeed, I think she possesses a natural fund of spirit, very much adapted to the character.—'Tis impossible, surely, that this hoyden can have a moment's attraction for Mr. Belville?

sp.speaker: Miss LEES.
sp.p: You are very obliging, ladies; but I have no turn for comedy; my fort is tragedy entirely.
Alphonso!—O, Alphonso! to thee I call. &c.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: But, my dear, is there none of our comedies to your taste?

sp.speaker: Miss LEES.
sp.p: O, yes; some of the sentimental ones are very pretty, there's such little difference between them and tragedies.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: And pray, my dear, how long have you been engaged to Mr. Frankly?

sp.speaker: Miss LEES.
sp.p: I only came away last night, and hav'n't seen Mr. Frankly since, tho' I expect him every moment.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Last night! just as Mrs. Tempest mentioned. aside.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: You had the concurrence of your friends?

sp.speaker: Miss LEES.
sp.p: Not I, Madam. Mr. Frankly said, I had too much genius to mind my friends, and as I should want nothing from them, there was no occasion to consult them in the affair.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Then Osbaldiston is not your real name, perhaps?

sp.speaker: Miss LEES.
sp.p: O no, nor do I tell my real name: I chose Osbaldiston, because it was a long one, and wou'd make a striking appearance in the bills.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: I wish we cou'd see Mr. Frankly.

sp.speaker: Miss LEES.
sp.p: Perhaps you may, Madam, for he designs to give me a lesson every day, 'till we are ready to set off for Ireland.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Suppose then, my dear, you wou'd oblige us with a scene in Juliet, by way of shewing your proficiency to Mrs. Belville.

sp.speaker: Miss LEES.
sp.p: Will you stand up for Romeo?

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: With all my heart, and I'll give you some instructions.

sp.speaker: Miss LEES.
sp.p: I beg pardon, Ma'am; I'll learn to act under nobody but Mr. Frankly. This room is without a carpet; if you will step into the next, ladies, I'll endeavour to oblige you.
Shall I not be environed, distraught—
This way, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, shew us the way.

div3.stage: Exeunt Miss LEES. and Lady RACH.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: I'll prolong this mummery as much as possible, in hopes the manager may come. Lye still, poor fluttering heart! it cannot be the lord of all your wishes! it cannot surely be your ador'd Belville! Exit.

sp.speaker: Miss LEES.
sp.p: Hav'n't I left my Romeo and Juliet here? O yes, there it is.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.l: —O, were those eyes in heav'n,

l.hi: They'd thro' the starry regions stream so bright,
That birds wou'd sing, and think it was the morn!

sp.speaker: Miss LEES.
sp.p: Ah, my dear Mr. Frankly! I am so glad you are come! I was dying to see you.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Kiss me, my dear;—why didn't you send me word of your intention to come away last night?

sp.speaker: Miss LEES.
sp.p: I hadn't time: but as I knew where the lodgings were, I thought I shou'd be able to find you by a note to the coffee-house I always directed to.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Kiss me again, my little sparkler!

sp.speaker: Miss LEES.
sp.p: Nay, I won't be kiss'd in this manner; for tho' I am going on the stage, I intend to have some regard for my character. But, ha, ha, ha, I am glad you are come now: I have company above stairs.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Company! that's unlucky at this time, for I wanted to make you intirely easy about your character. (aside.) And pray, my dear, who is your company? You know we must be very cautious for fear of your relations.

sp.speaker: Miss LEES.
sp.p: O, they are only ladies.—But one of them is the most beautiful creature in the world!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: The devil she is!

p.hi: An earth-treading star, that makes dim heav'ns light.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Zounds! I'll take a peep at the star, who knows but I may have an opporturiity of making another actress. aside.

sp.speaker: Miss LEES.
sp.p: Come, charmer! charmer!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.l: —Wer't thou as far
As that vast shore, wash'd by the farthest sea,
I wou'd adventure for such merchandize.
sp.p: Now let's see what fortune has sent us above stairs.

head.stage: SCENE changes to a Dining-room at Miss LEESON's.

div3.stage: Mrs. BELVILLE and Lady RACHEL discover'd.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: This is a most ignorant young creature, Lady Rachel.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Why I think she is—did you observe how she slighted my offer of instructing her?

sp.speaker: Miss LEES.
sp.p: Ladies!—ladies!—here he is! here is Mr. Frankly!

div3.stage: Enter Belville, bowing very low, not seeing the Ladies.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Ladies, your most obedient.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Let me, if possible, recollect myself— Sir, your most obedient humble servent.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Zounds! let me out of the house.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: What do I see!

sp.speaker: Miss LEES.
sp.p: You seem, ladies, to know this gentleman?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: (taking hold of him) You shan't go renegade—You laugh'd at my credulity this morning, and I must now laugh at your embarassment.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: What a kind thing it would be in any body to blow out my stupid brains?

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: I'll mark this down for an incident in my comedy.

sp.speaker: Miss LEES.
sp.p: What do you hang your head for Mr. Frankley?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Be so good as to ask that lady, my dear.— The Devil has been long in my debt, and now he pays me home with a witness.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: What a cruel thing it is to let Mrs. Tempest out, my love, without somebody to take care of her!

sp.speaker: Miss LEES.
sp.p: What, do you know Mrs. Tempest, madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Yes, my dear;—and I am pretty well acquainted with this gentleman.

sp.speaker: Miss LEES.
sp.p: What isn't this gentleman the manager of a play-house in Ireland?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: The curtain is almost dropt my dear; the farce is nearly over, and you'll be speedily acquainted with the catastrophe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEMP.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, the curtain is almost dropt: I have had spies to watch your haunts, and the catastrophe ends in your detection.—Come, you abandon'd slut,—

sp.speaker: Miss LEES.
sp.p: And have I elop'd after all, without being brought upon the stage?

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEMP.
sp.p: I don't know that you would be brought upon the stage; but I am sure you were near being brought upon the town. I hope, madam, for the future, you'll set me down a mad-woman.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Mr. Belvill, you'll make my apologies to this lady, and acknowledge that I think her perfectly in her senses.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I wish that I had intirely lost mine.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: (Writing) I wish that I had entirely lost mine. A very natural wish, in such a situation.

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEM.
sp.p: Come, you audacious minx, come away. You shall be sent into Yorkshire this very evening; and see what your poor mother will say to you, hussey.

sp.speaker: Miss LEES.
sp.p: I will go on the stage, if I die for't; and 'tis some comfort there's a play-house at York.

div3.stage: Exit Mrs. Tempest and Miss Leeson.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Nancy, I am so asham'd, so humbled, and so penitent, that if you knew what passes here, I am sure you wou'd forgive me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: My love, tho' I cannot say I rejoice in your infidelity, yet, believe me, I pity your distress: let us therefore think no more of this.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: (Writing.) And think no more of this. —This conduct is new in a wife, and very dramatic.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Where, my angel, have you acquired so many requisites to charm with?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: In your society, my dear; and believe me —that a wife may be as true a friend as any bottle companion upon earth, tho' she can neither get merry with you over night, nor blow out your brains about some foolish quarrel in the morning.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: If wives knew the omnipotence of virtue, where she wears a smile upon her face, they'd all follow your bewitching example, and make a faithless husband quite an incredible character.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Quite an incredible character!— Let me set down that. (writing.) Exeunt.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Yes, Horace, I have been just visiting at Belvill's.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: You found nobody at home, but Miss Walsingham?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: No, but I'd a long conversation with her, and upon a very interesting subject.

sp.speaker: CAPT
sp.p: 'Tis as I guess'd. aside.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: She is a most amiable creature, Horace.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: So she is, Sir, and will make any man happy that marries her.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I am glad you think so.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: He's glad I think so!—'tis plain,—but I must leave every thing to himself, and seem wholly passive in the affair. aside.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: A married life after all, Horace, I am now convinced is the most happy, as well as the most reputable.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: It is indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Then perhaps you wou'd have no objection to be married, if I offered you as agreeable a young woman as Miss Walsingham.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: 'Twou'd be my first pride on every occasion, Sir, to pay an implicit obedience to your commands.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: That's sensibly said, Horace, and obligingly said; prepare yourself therefore for an introduction to the lady in the morning.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Is the lady prepar'd to receive me, Sir?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: O yes; and you can't think how highly delighted Miss Walsingham appeared, when I acquainted her with my resolution on the subject.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: She's all goodness!

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: The more I know her, the more I am charm'd with her; I must not be explicit with him yet, for fear my secret should get wind, and reach the ears of the enemy. aside.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I propose, Horace, that you should be married immediately.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: The sooner the better, Sir, I have no will but your's.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: (Shaking hands with him,) By the memory of Malbro', you are a most excellent boy!—But what do you think? Miss Walsingham insists upon naming the day.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: And welcome, Sir; I am sure she won't make it a distant one.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: O she said, that nothing in her power shou'd be wanting to make you happy.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: I am sure of that, Sir.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: [A loud knocking] Zounds, Horace! here's the disgrace and punishment of my life: Let's avoid her as we would a fever in the camp.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Come to the library, and I'll tell you how whimsically she was treated this morning at Belville's.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Death and the devil! make haste. O I must laugh at marriage, and be curst to me! But I am providing, Horace, against your falling into my error.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: I am eternally indebted to you, Sir.

div3.head: SCENE, BELVILLE's House.
div3.stage: Enter Mrs. Belville and Lady Rachel.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Nay; Mrs. Belville, I have no patience, you act quite unnaturally.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: What! because I am unwilling to be miserable?

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: This new instance of Mr. Belville's infidelity—This attempt to seduce Miss Walsingham, which your woman overheard, is unpardonable!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: I don't say but that I am strongly wounded by his irregularities. Yet if Mr. Belville is unhappily a rover, I wou'd much rather that he should have twenty mistresses than one.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: You astonish me!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Why, don't you know, my dear madam, that while he is divided amidst a variety of objects, 'tis impossible for him to have a serious attachment?

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Lord, Mrs. Belville! how can you speak with so much composure! a virtuous woman should be always outrageous upon such an occasion as this.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: What, and weary the innocent sun and moon from the firmament, like a despairing princess in a tragedy—No—no—Lady Rachel, 'tis bad enough to be indifferent to the man I love, without studying to excite his aversion.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: How glad I am that Miss Walsingham made him so heartily asham'd of himself: Lord, these young men are so full of levity: Give me a husband of Mr. Torrington's age, say I.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: And give me a husband of Mr. Belville's, say I, with all his follies: However, Lady Rachel, I am pretty well satisfied that my conduct at Miss Leeson's will have a proper effect upon Mr. Belville's generosity, and put an entire end to his galantries for the future.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Don't deceive yourself, my dear.— The gods in the shilling gallery would sooner give up Roast Beef, or go without an epilogue on the first night of a new piece.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Why should you, think so of such a man as Mr. Belville?

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Because Mr. Belville is a man: However, if you dare run the risque—we will try the sincerity of his reformation.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: If I dare run the risque! I would stake my soul upon his honour.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Then your poor soul would be in a very terrible situation.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: By what test can we prove his sincerity?

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: By a very simple one. You know I write so like Miss Walsingham, that our hands are scarcely known asunder.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Well—

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Why then let me write to him as from her—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: If I did not think it would look like a doubt of his honour—

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Poh! dare you proceed upon my plan?—

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Most confidently: Come to my dressing-room, where you'll find every thing ready for writing, and then you may explain your scheme more particularly.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
