sp.p: I'll attend you, but I am really sorry, my dear, for the love of propriety, to see you so calm under the perfidy of your husband; you should be quite wretched—indeed you should. Ex.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: The hell-hounds are after me.
sp.stage: Enter Connolly, at the opposite side.
sp.p: Fly, open the chambers this moment, the bailiffs are in sight.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Faith and that I will; but it will be of no use to fly a step, if I hav'n't the key.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Zounds! did not you lock the door?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Yes; but I believe I left the key on the inside: However, I see no more than three people, and think we could beat them to their hearts content in three minutes.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: What! and fly in the face of the law?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: To be sure you have a great regard for the law, when you are going to fight a duel!

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: S'death! is this a time to talk? Stay here, and throw every possible impediment in the way of these execrable rascals. (going.)

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Holloa! honey, come back: These execrable rascals are very worthy people, I fancy, for they are quietly turning down the next court.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Their appearance alarm'd me beyond measure.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: O you shou'dn't judge by outside shew, my dear; for there is no being a complete rogue, without the appearance of an honest man

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Circumstanced as I am at present, every thing terrifies me; for should I be arrested, the consequence would possibly be fatal, both to my honour and my love.—Belville would proclaim me publicly a coward; and Emily set me down as a base, a mercenary adventurer, who was solely attracted by her fortune.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Why faith, honey, like yourself, they might be apt to judge by appearances.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: O, Connolly, a man of spirit should learn prudence from his very pride, and consider every unnecessary debt he contracts as a wanton diminution of his character! the moment he makes another his creditor—he makes himself a slave! He runs the hazard of insults, which he never can resent, and of disgraces which are seldom to be mitigated! He incurs the danger of being dragg'd, like the vilest felon to the felon's prison! and, such is the depravity of the world, that guilt is even more likely to meet with advocates, than misfortune! Exit Leeson.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p:
Musha, long life to you, ould Shillala!—I wish I had any thing besides my carcase to venture for you, for that's nothing; yet you are as welcome to it as the flowers in May. Poor lad! I don't wonder that he is so much afraid of a prison, for to be sure it is a blessed place to live in; and a blessed law it must be, which coops a man up from every chance of getting money, by way of making him pay his debts—But now let my thick skull consider, if there is any method of preventing this infernal duel. Suppose I have him
bound over to the pace! No, that will never do—it would be a shameful thing for a gintleman to keep the pace! Besides, I must appear in the business, and people may think, from my connexion with him, that he has not honour enough to throw away his life: Suppose I go another way to work, and send an anonymous letter about the affair to Mrs. Belville: They say, though she is a woman of fashion, that no creter upon earth can be fonder of her husband. Surely the good genius of Ireland put this scheme into my head—I'll about it this minute; and if there's only one of them kept from the field, I don't think that the other can be much hurt, when there will be no body to fight with him. Exit.

head.stage: SCENE, changes to Capt. SAVAGE's Lodgings.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Why, faith, Belville, your detection, and so speedily too, after all the pretended sanctity of the morning, must have thrown you into a most humiliating situation.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Into the most distressing you can imagine: had my wife rav'd at my falsehood, in the customary manner, I cou'd have brazen'd it but pretty tollerably; but the angel-like sweetness, with which she bore the mortifying discovery, planted daggers in my bosom, and made me at that time wish her the veriest vixen in the whole creation.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Yet, the suffering forbearance of a wife, is a quality for which she is seldom allow'd her merit; we think it her duty to put up with our falsehood, and imagine ourselves exceedingly generous in the main, if we practise no other method of breaking her heart.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
Monstrous! monstrous! from this moment
I bid an everlasting adieu to my vices: the generosity of my dear girl—

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Here's a letter, Sir, which Mr. Spruce has brought you.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Give me leave, Savage.—Zounds! what an industrious devil the father of darkness is, when the moment a man determines upon a good action, he sends such a thing as this, to stagger his resolution.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: What have you got there?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: You shall know presently. Will you let Spruce come in.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Where have you acquir'd all this ceremony?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Bid Spruce come in.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Is that another challenge?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: 'Tis upon my soul, but it came from a beautiful enemy, and dares me to give a meeting to Miss Walsingham.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Pray, Spruce, who gave you this letter?

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: Miss Walsingham's woman, Sir: she said it was about very particular business, and therefore I wou'dn't trust it by any of the footmen.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: O, damn your diligence. aside.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: You may go home, Spruce.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: (Looking significantly at his Master.) Is there no answer necessary, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I shall call at home myself, and give the necessary answer.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: (Aside.) What can be the matter with him all of a sudden, that he is so cold upon the scent of wickedness? Exit.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: And what answer do you propose making to it, Belville?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Read the letter, and then tell me what I shou'd do.—You know Miss Walsingham's hand.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: O, perfectly!—This is not—yes, it is her hand!—I have too many curst occasions to know it.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: What are you a muttering about?—Read the letter.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: If you are not entirely discouraged, by our last conversation, from renewing the subject which then gave offence—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Which then gave offence.—You see, Savage, that it is not offensive any longer.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Sdeath! you put me out.—you may at the masquerade, this evening—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: You remember how earnest she was for the masquerade party.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I remember it well:—and I remember, also, how hurt she was this morning, about the affair of Miss Leeson. (aside.) —have an opportunity of entertaining me—O the strumpet! aside.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: But mind the cunning with which she signs the note, for fear it shou'd by any accident fall into improper hands.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Ay, and you put it into very proper hands. (aside.) I shall be in the blue domino.—The signature is— YOU KNOW WHO.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Yes, you know who.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: May be, however, she has only written this to try you.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: To try me, for what purpose? But if you read a certain postcript there, I fancy you'll be of a different opinion.

p.hi: If Mr. Belville has any house of character to retire to, it wou'd be most agreeable, as there cou'd be no fear of interruption.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
What do you say now?—Can you recommend
me to any house of character, where we shall be free from interruption.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: O, curse her house of character! (aside) But surely, Belville, after your late determin'd resolution to reform—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Zounds! I forgot that.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: After the unexampled sweetness of your wife's behaviour—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Don't go on, Savage: There is something here (putting his hand upon his bosom) which feels already not a little aukwardly.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: And can you still persist?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I am afraid to answer your question.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Where the plague are you flying?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: From the justice of your censure, Horace; my own is sufficiently severe; yet I see that I shall be a rascal again, in spite of my teeth; and good advice is only thrown away upon so incorrigible a libertine.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: (alone) So then this diamond of mine proves a counterfeit after all, and I am really the veriest wretch existing at the moment in which I conceiv'd myself the peculiar favourite of fortune. O the cursed, cursed sex! I'll see her once more to upbraid her with her falsehood, then acquaint my father with her perfidy, to justify my breaking off the marriage, and tear her from my thoughts for ever.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Sir! Sir! Sir!—

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, Sir,—What the devil's the matter with the booby?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Miss Walsingham, Sir!

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Ah! what of her?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Was this moment overturn'd at Mr. Belville's door, and John tells me carried in a fit into the house.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Ha! let me fly to her assistance. Exit.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Ha let me fly to her assistance—O, are you thereabouts. Exit.

div3.stage: Enter Mrs. Belville, Miss Walsingham and Lady Rachel Mildew.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: But are you indeed recover'd my dear?

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Perfectly my dear,—I wasn't in the least hurt, tho' greatly terrified, when the two fools of coachmen contended for the honour of being first, and drove the carriages together with a violence incredible.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: I sincerely rejoice at your escape; and now Mrs. Belville, as you promised to choose a dress for me if I went in your party to the masquerade this evening, can you spare a quarter of an hour to Tavistock-Street?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: I am loth to leave Miss Walsingham alone, Lady Rachel, so soon after her fright.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL
sp.p: Nay, I insist that you don't stay at home upon my account; and Lady Rachel's company to the masquerade is a pleasure I have such an interest in, that I beg you won't delay a moment to oblige her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Well, then I attend your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: You are very good; and so is Miss Walsingham. Exit.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: I wonder Captain Savage stays away so long! where can he be all this time?—I die with impatience to tell him of my happy interview with the General.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Captain Savage, madam.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Shew him in. [Exit Serv.] How he must rejoice to find his conjectures so fortunately realiz'd.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: So, madam, you have just escap'd a sad accident

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: And by that agreeable tone and countenance, one would almost imagine you were very sorry for my escape.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: People, madam, who doubt the kindness of others, are generally conscious of some defect in themselves.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Don't madam me, with this accent of indifference. What has put you out of humour?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Are you indispos'd?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: The Crocodile! the Crocodile! aside.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Do you go to the masquerade to night?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: No, but you do.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Why not? come, don't be ill-natur'd, I'm not your wife yet.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Nor ever will be, I promise you.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: What is the meaning of this very whimsical behaviour?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: The settled composure of her impudence is intolerable. (aside.) Madam, Madam, how have I deserv'd this usage?

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, Sir, how have I deserved it, if you go to that?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: The letter, madam!—the letter!

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: What letter?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Your letter, inviting a gallant from the masquerade to a house of character, madam!—What, you appear surpriz'd?

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Well I may, at so shameless an aspersion.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p:
Madam, madam, I have seen your letter!
Your new lover cou'dn't keep your secret a moment. But I have nothing to do with you,—and only come to declare my reasons for renouncing you everlastingly!

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: General Savage, madam.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Shew him up. [Exit Serv.] I am glad he is come, Sir; inform him of your resolution to break off the match, and let there be an end of every thing between us.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: The news of your accident reach'd me but this moment, madam,—or I shou'd have posted much sooner to reconnoitre your situation. My aid de camp, however, has not been inattentive I see, and I dare say his diligence will not be the least lessen'd, when he knows his obligations to you.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: O, Sir, I am perfectly sensible of my obligations; and the consciousness of them, was one motive of my coming here.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Then you have made your acknowledgements to miss Walsingham I hope.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: He has indeed, General, said a great deal more than was necessary.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: That opinion proceeds from the liberality of your temper; for 'tis impossible he can ever say enough of your goodness.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: So it is; if you knew but all, Sir.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Why who can know more of the matter than myself?

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: This gentleman, it seems, has something, General Savage, very necessary for your information.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p:
Nay, Sir, I only say, that for some particular reasons, which I shall communicate to you at a
more proper time; I must beg leave to decline the lady whose hand you kindly intended for me this morning.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: O you must!—Why then I hope you decline at the same time, all pretensions to every shilling of my fortune. It is not in my power to make you fight, you paltroon, but I can punish you for cowardice.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Nay, but General, let me interpose here. If he can maintain any charge against the lady's repuation, 'twould be very hard that he should be disinherited, for a necessary attention to his honour.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: And if I don't make the charge good, I submit to be disinherited without murmurring.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: 'Tis false as hell! the lady is infinitely too good for you, in every respect; and I undervalued her worth, when I thought of her for your wife.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: I am sure the lady is much oblig'd to your favourable opinion, Sir.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Not in the least, Madam; I only do her common justice.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: I cannot bear that you shou'd be displeas'd a moment, Sir; suffer me therefore to render the conversation less equivocable, and a few words will explain every thing.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Sirrah, I'll hear no explanation; ar'n't my orders that you shou'd marry?

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: For my sake hear him, General Savage.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Madam, I disdain every favour that is to be procur'd by your interposition. Exit.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: This matter must not be suffer'd to proceed farther tho', provokingly, cruelly as the Captain has behav'd. aside.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: What's that you say, my bewitching girl?

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: I say that you must make it up with the Captain, and the best way will be to hear his charge patiently.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I am shock'd at the brutality of the dog; he has no more principle than a suttler, and no more steadiness than a young recruit upon drill. But, you shall have ample satisfaction:—this very day I'll cut him off from a possibility of succeeding to a shilling of my fortune. He shall be as miserable as—

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Dear General, do you think that this wou'd give me any satisfaction?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: How he became acquainted with my design I know not, but I see plainly, that his mutiny proceeds from his aversion to my marrying again.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: To your marrying again, Sir! why shou'd he object to that?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Why, for fear I should have other children, to be sure.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, it was not from that motive; and, if I can overlook his folly, you may be prevail'd upon to forgive it.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: After what you have seen, justice shou'd make you a little more attentive to your own interest, my lovely girl.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: What at the expence of his?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: In the approaching change of your situation, there may be a family of your own.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Suppose there shou'd, Sir; won't there be a family of his too?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I care not what becomes of his family.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: But, pray let me think a little about it, General.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: 'Tis hard, indeed, when I was so desirous of promoting his happiness, that he should throw any thing in the way of mine.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Recollect, Sir, his offence was wholly confin'd to me.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Well, my love, and isn't it throwing an obstacle in the way of my happiness, when he abuses you so grosly for your readiness to marry me?

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Sir!—

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I see, with all your good nature, that this is a question you cannot rally against.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: It is indeed, Sir.—What will become of me? aside.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: You seem suddenly disordered, my love?

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Why really, Sir, this affair affects me strongly.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Well, it is possible, that for your sake, I may not punish him with as much severity as I intended: In about an hour I shall beg leave to beat up your quarters again, with Mr. Torrington; for 'tis necessary I should shew you some proof of my gratitude, since you have been so kindly pleas'd to honour me with a proof of your affection.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: (aside.) So, now indeed, we're in a hopeful situation. Exeunt.

div3.stage: Enter Mrs. Belville, and Captain Savage.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: DON'T argue with me, Captain Savage; but consider that I am a wife, and pity my distraction.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Dear Madam, there is no occasion to be so much alarm'd; Mr. Belville has very properly determin'd not to fight; he told me so himself, and should have been effectually prevented, if I hadn't known his resolution.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: There is no knowing to what extremities he may be provok'd, if he meets Mr. Leeson; I have sent for you, therefore, to beg that you will save him from the possibility, either of exposing himself to any danger, or of doing an injury to his adversary.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: What would you have me do, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Fly to Hyde park, and prevent, if yet possible, his meeting with Mr. Leeson: Do it, I conjure you, if you'd save me from desperation.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Though you have no reason whatever to be apprehensive for his safety, Madam, yet, since you are so very much affected, I'll immediately execute your commands. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Merciful heaven! where is the generosity, where is the sense, where is the shame of men, to find a pleasure in pursuits, which they cannot remember without the deepest horror; which they cannot follow without the meanest fraud; and which they cannot effect, without consequences the most dreadful? The single word, Pleasure, in a masculine sense, comprehends every thing that is cruel; every thing that is base; and every thing that is desperate: Yet men, in other respects, the noblest of their species, make it the principal business of their lives, and do not hesitate to break in upon the peace of the happiest families, though their own must be necessarily expos'd to destruction.—O Belville! Belville!—my life! my love!—The greatest triumph which a libertine can ever experience, is too despicable to be envied; 'tis at best nothing but a victory over his own humanity; and if he is a husband, he must be dead indeed, if he is not doubly tortured upon the wheel of recollection.

div3.stage: Enter Miss WALSINGHAM and Lady RACHEL MILDEW.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: My dear Mrs. Belville, I am extremely unhappy to see you so distress'd.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Now, I am extremely glad to see her so, for if she wasn't greatly distress'd it wou'd be monstrously unnatural.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: O, Matilda!—my husband! my husband! my children! my children!

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Don't weep, my dear! don't weep! pray be comforted, all may end happily. Lady Rachel, beg of her not to cry so.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Why, you are crying yourself, Miss Walsingham; and tho' I think it out of character to encourage her tears, I can't help keeping you company.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: O, why is not some effectual method contriv'd, to prevent this horrible practice of duelling?

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: I'll expose it on the stage, since the law now a-days, kindly leaves the whole cognizance of it to the theatre.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: And yet if the laws against it, were as well enforced as the laws against destroying the game, perhaps it would be equally for the benefit of the kingdom.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: No law will ever be effectual till the custom is render'd infamous.—Wives must shriek! —mothers must agonize!—orphans must multiply! unless some blessed hand strips the fascinating glare from honourable murder, and bravely exposes the idol who is worship'd thus in blood. While it is disreputable to obey the laws, we cannot look for reformation:—But if the duellist is once banished from the presence of his sovereign;—if he is for life excluded the confidence of his country;—if a mark of indelible disgrace is stamp'd upon him, the sword of publick justice will be the sole chastiser of wrongs; trifles will not be punish'd with death, and offences really meriting such a punishment, will be reserv'd for the only proper avenger, the common executioner.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: I cou'dn't have express'd myself better on the subject, my dear: but till such a hand as you talk of is found, the best will fall into the error of the times.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Yes, and butcher each other like madmen, for fear their courage should be suspected by fools.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: No news yet from Captain Savage?

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: He can't have reach'd Hyde-park yet, my dear.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Let us lead you to you chamber, my dear; you'll be better there.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Matilda, I must be wretched any where; but I'll attend you.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Thank heav'n, I have no husband to plunge me into such a situation!

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: And, if I thought I cou'd keep my resolution, I'd determine this moment on living single all the days of my life. Pray don't spare my arm, my dear. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I fancy I am rather before the time of appointment; engagements of this kind are the only ones, in which, now-a-days, people pretend, to any punctuality:—a man is allow'd half an hours law to dinner, but a thrust through the body must be given within a second of the clock.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Your servant, Sir.—Your name I suppose is Belville?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Your supposition is very right, Sir; and I fancy I am not much in the wrong, when I suppose your name to be Leeson.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: It is, Sir; I am sorry I shou'd keep you here a moment.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I am very sorry, Sir, you shou'd bring me here at all.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: I regret the occasion, be assured, Sir; but 'tis not now a time for talking, we must proceed to action.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: And yet talking is all the action I shall proceed to, depend upon it.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: What do you mean, Sir? Where are your pistols?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Where I intend they shall remain till my next journey into the country, very quietly over the chimney in my dressing room.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: You treat this matter with too much levity, Mr. Belville; take your choice of mine, Sir.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I'd rather take them both, if you please, for then no mischief shall be done with either of them.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Sir, this trifling is adding insult to injury; and shall be resented accordingly. Didn't you come here to give me satisfaction?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Yes, every satisfaction in my power.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Take one of these pistols then.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Come, Mr. Leeson, your bravery will not at all be lessen'd by the exercise of a little understanding: If nothing less than my life can atone for the injury I have unconsciously done you, fire at me instantly, but don't be offended because I decline to do you an additional wrong.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: S'death, Sir, do you think I come here with an intention to murder?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: You come to arm the guilty against the innocent, Sir; and that, in my opinion, is the most atrocious intention of murder.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: How's this?—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Look'e, Mr. Leeson, there's your pistol (throws it on the ground) I have already acted very wrongly with respect to your sister, but, Sir, I have some character (though perhaps little enough) to maintain, and I will not do a still worse action, in raising my hand against your life.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: This hypocrital cant of cowardice, Sir, is too palpable to disarm my resentment; though I held you to be a man of profligate principles, I nevertheless consider'd you as a man of courage; but, if you hesitate a moment longer, by heaven, I'll chastise you on the spot. (Draws.)

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I must defend my life; though if it did not look like timidity, I would inform you— (they fight, Leeson is disarmed) —Mr. Leeson, there is your sword again.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Strike it through my bosom, Sir;—I don't desire to out-live this instant,

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
I hope, my dear Sir, that you will long live
happy—as your sister, tho' to my shame I can claim no merit on that account, is recovered unpolluted, by her family; but let me beg that you will now see the folly of decisions by the sword, when success is not fortunately chain'd to the side of justice: Before I leave you, receive my sincerest apologies for the injuries I have done you; and, be assured, no occurrence will ever give me greater pleasure, than an opportunity of serving you, if, after what is past, you shall at any time condescend to use me as a friend. Ex.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Very well—very well—very well.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: What, you have been within hearing, I suppose?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: You may say that.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: And isn't this very fine?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Why I can't say much as to the finery of it, Sir, but it is certainly very foolish.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: And so this is my satisfaction after all!

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Yes, and pretty satisfaction it is. When Mr. Belville did you but one injury, he was the greatest villain in the world; but now that he has done you two, in drawing his sword upon you, I suppose he is a very worthy gentleman

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: To be foil'd, baffled, disappointed in my revenge!—What tho' my sister is by accident unstain'd, his intentions are as criminal, as if her ruin was actually perpetrated; there is no possibility of enduring the reflection!—I wish not for the blood of my enemy, but I would at least have the credit of giving him life.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Arrah, my dear, if you had any regard for the life of your enemy, you shou'dn't put him in the way of death.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: No more of these reflections, my dear Connolly; my own feelings are painful enough. Will you be so good as to take these damn'd pistols, and come with me to the coach?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p:
Troth and that I will; but don't make yourself
uneasy; consider that you have done every thing which honour required at yous hands.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: I hope so.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Why you know so: You have broke the laws of heaven and earth, as nobly as the first lord in the land, and you have convinc'd the world, that where any body has done your family one injury, you have courage enough to do it another yourself, by hazarding your life.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Those, Connolly, who would live reputably in any country, must regulate their conduct in many cases by its very prejudices.—Custom, with respect to duelling, is a tyrant, whose despotism no body ventures to attack, tho' every body detests its cruelty.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: I didn't imagine that a tyrant of any kind would be tolerated in England. But where do you think of going now? For chambers, you know, are at present most delightfully dangerous.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: I shall go to Mrs. Crayon's.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: What the gentlewoman that paints all manner of colours in red chalk?

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Yes, where I first became acquainted with Emily.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: And where the sweet creature has met you two or three times under pretence of sitting for her picture.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Mrs. Crayons will, I dare say, oblige me in this exigency with an apartment for a few days; but come, Connolly, we have no time to lose, tho' if you had any prudence, you would abandon me in my present situation.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Ah, Sir, is this your opinion of my friendship? Do you think that any thing can ever give me half so much pleasure in serving you, as seeing you surrounded by misfortunes. Exeunt.

head.stage: The Scene changes to an Apartment at Belville's.

div3.stage: Enter General Savage, Torrington, and Spruce.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: Miss Walsingham will wait on you im-immediately, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: (aside) What can old Holifernes want so continually with Miss Walsingham? Exit

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: When I bring this sweet mild creature home, I shall be able to break her spirit to my own wishes— I'll inure her to proper discipline from the first moment, and make her tremble at the very thought of mutiny.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Ah, General, you are wonderfully brave, when you know the meekness of your adversary.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Envy, Torrington—stark, staring envy: few fellows, on the borders of fifty, have so much reason as myself, to boast of a blooming young woman's partiality.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: On the borders of fifty, man!—beyond the confines of threescore.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: The more reason I have to boast of my victory then; but don't grumble at my triumph, you shall have a kiss of the bride, let that content you, Torrington.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Gentlemen, your most obedient: General, I intended writing to you about a trifling mistake; but poor Mrs. Belville has been so very ill, that I cou'dn't find an opportunity.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I am very sorry for Mrs. Belville's illness, but I am happy, Madam, to be personally in the way of receiving your commands, and I wait upon you with Mr. Torrington, to talk about a marriage settlement

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Heavens! how shall I undeceive him?

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: 'Tis rather an aukward business, Miss Walsingham, to trouble you upon; but as the General wishes that the affair may be as private as possible, he thought it better to speak to yourself, than to treat with any other person.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p:
Yes, my lovely girl; and to convince you,
that I intend to carry on an honourable war, not to pillage like a free-booter, Mr. Torrington will be a trustee.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: I am infinitely oblig'd to your intention, but there's no necessity to talk about any settlement—for—

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Pardon me, Madam,—pardon me, there is— besides, I have determin'd that there shall be one, and what I once determine is absolute.—A tolerable hint for her own behaviour, when I have married her, Torrington. aside to Tor.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: I must not shock him before Mr. Torrington (aside). General Savage, will you give me leave to speak a few words in private to you.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: There is no occasion for sounding a retreat, Madam; Mr. Torrington is acquainted with the whole business, and I am determin'd, for your sake, that nothing shall be done without him.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: I can have no objection to your hearing the lady ex parte, General.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: What I have to say, Sir, is of a very particular nature.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: (rising) I'll leave the room then.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: (opposing him) You shan't leave the room, Torrington. Miss Walsingham shall have a specimen of my command, even before marriage, and you shall see, that every woman is not to bully me out of my determination. (aside to Tor.)

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Well, General, you must have your own way.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: (to Tor.) Don't you see that it's only fighting the battle stoutly at first, with one of these gentle creatures?

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: (significantly) Ah, General!

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I own, Madam, your situation is a distressing one; let us sit down—let us sit down—

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: It is unspeakably distressing indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p:
Distressing however as it may be, we must proceed
to issue, Madam; the General proposes your jointure to be 1000 l. a year.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: General Savage!

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: You think this too little, perhaps?

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: I can't think of any jointure, Sir.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Why to be sure, a jointure it at best but a melancholly possession, for it must be purchased by the loss of the husband you love.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Pray don't name it, Mr. Torrington.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: (kissing her hand) A thousand thanks to you, my lovely girl.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: For heaven's sake, let go my hand.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I shall be mad 'till it gives me legal possession of the town.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Gentlemen—General—Mr. Torrington—I beg you'll hear me.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: By all means, my adorable creature; I can never have too many proofs of your disinterested affection.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: There is a capital mistake in this whole affair—I am sinking under a load of distress.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Your confusion makes you look charmingly though.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: There is no occasion to talk of jointures or marriages to me; I am not going to be married.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: What's this?

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Nor have I an idea in nature, however enviable I think the honour, of being your wife, Sir.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Why here's a demur!

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: I am afraid, Sir, that in our conversation this morning, my confusion arising from the particularity of the subject, has led you into a material misconception.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I am thunderstruck, madam! I cou'dn't mistake my ground.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: As clear a nol: pros: as ever was issued by an attorney general.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p:
Surely you can't forget, that at the first word you hung out a flag of truce, told me even
that I had a previous friend in the fort, and didn't so much as hint at a single article of capitulation?

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Now for the rejoinder to this replication.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: All this is unquestionably true, General, and perhaps a good deal more; but in reality my confusion before you on this subject to day, was such, that I scarcely knew what I said; I was dying with distress, and at this moment am very little better;— permit me to retire, General Savage, and only suffer me to add, that tho' I think myself highly flatter'd by your addresses, it is impossible for me ever to receive them. Lord! Lord! I am glad its over in any manner. Ex.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Why, we are a little out in this matter, General; the judge has decided against us, when we imagin'd ourselves sure of the cause.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: The gates shut in my teeth, just as I expected the keys from the governor.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: I am disappointed myself, man; I shan't have a kiss of the bride.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: At my time of life too!

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: I said from the first you were too old for her.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Zounds to fancy myself sure of her, and to triumph upon a certainty of victory.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Ay, and to kiss her hand in a rapturous return for her tenderness to you:—let me advise you never to kiss before folks, as long as you live again.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Don't distract me, Torrington! a joke, where a friend has the misfortune to lose the battle, is a downright inhumanity.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: You told me that your son had accus'd her of something that you would not hear; suppose we call at his lodgings, he perhaps, as an amicus-curiae, may be able to give us a little information.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Thank you for the thought;—But keep your finger more than ever upon you lips, dear Torrington. You know how I dread the danger of ridicule, and it wou'd be too much, not only to be thrash'd out of the field, but to be laugh'd at into the bargain.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: I thought when you made a presentment of your sweet person to Miss Walsingham, that the bill wou'd be return'd ignoramus. Exeunt.

div3.head: SCENE, BELVILLE's.
div3.stage: Mrs. BELVILLE and Lady RACHEL MILDEW, discovered on a Sopha.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: You heard what Captain Savage said?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: I would flatter myself, but my heart will not suffer it; the Park might be too full for the horrid purpose, and perhaps they are gone to decide the quarrel in some other place.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: The Captain enquir'd of numbers in the Park without hearing a syllable of them, and is therefore positive that they are parted without doing any mischief.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: I am, nevertheless, torn by a thousand apprehensions, and my fancy, with a gloomy kind of fondness, fastens on the most deadly, This very morning, I exultingly numbered myself in the catalogue of the happiest wives.—Perhaps I am a wife no longer;—perhaps, my little innocents, your unhappy father is at this moment breathing his last sigh, and wishing, O, how vainly! that he had not prefer'd a guilty pleasure to his own life, to my eternal peace of mind, and your felicity!

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: Madam! madam! my master! my master!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Is he safe?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: My love!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: O Mr. Belville! faints.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Assistance, quick!

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: There she revives.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: The angel-softness! how this rends my heart?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p:
O, Mr. Belville, if you cou'd conceive
the agonies I have endur'd, you would avoid the possibility of another quarrel as long as you liv'd, out of common humanity.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: My dearest creature, spare these tender reproaches; you know not how sufficiently I am punish'd to see you thus miserable.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: That's pleasant indeed, when you have yourself deliberately loaded her with affliction.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Pray, pray Lady Rachel, have a little mercy: Your poor humble servant has been a very naughty boy,—but if you only forgive him this single time, he will never more deserve the rod of correction.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Since you are return'd safe, I am happy. Excuse these foolish tears, they gush in spite of me.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: How contemptible do they render me, my love!

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Come, my dear, you must turn your mind from this gloomy subject.—Suppose we step up stairs and communicate our pleasure to Miss Walsingham?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: With all my heart. Adieu, recreant!

div3.stage: Exeunt Mrs. Bel. and Lady Rach.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I don't deserve such a woman, I don't deserve her.—Yet, I believe I am the first husband, that ever found fault with a wife, for having too much goodness.
What's the matter?

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: Your sister—

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: What of my sister?

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: Sir, is elop'd.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: My sister!

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: There is a letter left, Sir, in which she says, that her motive was a dislike to a match with Captain Savage, as she has plac'd her affections unalterably on another gentleman.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Death and damnation!

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p:
Mrs. Moreland, your mother, is in the greatest distress, Sir, and begs you will immediately
go with the servant that brought the message; for he observing the young lady's maid carrying some bundles out, a little suspiciously, thought there must be some scheme going on, and dogg'd a hackney coach, in which Miss Morland went off, to the very house where it set her down.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Bring me to the servant, instantly;—but don't let a syllable of this matter reach my wife's ears, her spirits are already too much agitated. Exit.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: Zounds! we shall be paid home, for the tricks we have play'd in other families. Exit.

head.stage: Scene changes to Capt. SAVAGE's Lodgings.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: The vehemence of my resentment against this abandon'd woman has certainly led me too far. I shou'dn't have acquainted her with my discovery of her baseness;—no, if I had acted properly, I should have conceal'd all knowledge of the transaction 'till the very moment of her guilt, and then burst upon her when she was solacing with her paramour, in all the fulness of security. Now, if she should either alter her mind, with respect to going to the masquerade, or go in a different habit to elude my observation, I not only lose the opportunity of exposing her, but give her time to plan some plausible excuse for her infamous letter to Belville.

sp.speaker: SER.
sp.p: General Savage, and Mr. Torrington, Sir.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: You blockhead, why did you let them wait a moment? What can be the meaning of this visit?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I come, Horace, to talk to you about Miss Walsingham.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: She's the most worthless woman existing, Sir: I can convince you of it.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I have already chang'd my own opinion of her.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: What you have found her out yourself, Sir?

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Yes, he has made a trifling discovery.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: S'death, don't make me contemptible to my son. aside to TOR.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: But, Sir, what instance of her precious behaviour has come to your knowledge? For an hour has scarcely elapsed, since you thought her a miracle of goodness

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Ay, he has thought her a miracle of goodness, within this quarter of an hour.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Why she has a manner that wou'd impose upon all the world.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Yes, but she has a manner also to undeceive the world thoroughly.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: That we have found pretty recently; however, in this land of liberty, none are to be pronounced guilty, 'till they are positively convicted; I can't therefore find against Miss Walsingham, upon the bare strength of presumptive evidence.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Presumptive evidence! hav'n't I promis'd you ocular demonstration?

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Ay, but 'till we receive this demonstration, my good friend, we cannot give judgement.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Then I'll tell you at once, who is the object of her honourable affections.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Who— who—

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: What would you think if they were plac'd on Belville?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Upon Belville! has she deserted to him from the corps of virtue?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Yes, she wrote to him, desiring to be taken from the masquerade to some convenient scene of privacy, and tho' I have seen the letter, she has the impudence to deny her own hand.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: What a fiend is there then disguis'd under the uniform of an angel!

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: The delicate creature that was dying with confusion!

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Only come with me to the masquerade, and you shall see Belville carry her off: 'Twas about the scandalous appointment with him, I was speaking, when you conceiv'd I treated her so rudely.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: And you were only anxious to shew her in her real character to me, when I was so exceedingly offended with you.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Nothing else in the world, Sir; I knew you would despise and detest her, the moment you were acquainted with her baseness.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: How she brazen'd it out before my face, and what a regard she affected for your interest! I was a madman not to listen then to your explanation.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Tho' you both talk this point well, I still see nothing but strong presumption against Miss Walsingham: Mistakes have already happened, mistakes may happen again; and I will not give up a lady's honour, upon an evidence that wou'd not cast a common pickpocket at the Old Baily.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Come to the masquerade then and be convinc'd.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Let us detach a party for dresses immediately. Yet remember, Torrington, that the punctuality of evidence which is necessary in a court of law, is by no means requisite in a court of honour.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Perhaps it would be more to the honour of your honourable courts if it was. Exeunt.

head.stage: The Scene changes to an Apartment at Mrs. Crayon's,

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: (behind.) My dear, you must excuse me.

sp.speaker: MAID.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, you must not go up stairs.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Indeed but I will; the man is positive to the house, and I'll search every room in it, from the cellar to the garret, if I don't find the lady. James, don't stir from the street door.

div3.stage: Enter Belville followed by a Maid.

sp.speaker: MAID
sp.p:
Sir, you are the strangest gentleman I ever
met with in all my born days:—I wish my mistress was at home.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I am a strange fellow, my dear—But if your mistress was at home, I shou'd take the liberty of peeping into the apartments.

sp.speaker: MAID.
sp.p: Sir, there's company in that room, you can't go in there.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Now that's the very reason I will go in.

sp.speaker: MAID.
sp.p: This must be some great man, or he wou'dn't behave so obstropolous.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Good manners by your leave a little. (forcing the door.) Whoever my gentleman is, I'll call him to a severe reckoning:—I have been just call'd to one myself, for making free with another man's sister.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Who is it that dares commit an outrage upon this apartment?

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: An Englishman's very lodging; ay, and an Irishman's too, I hope, is his castle;—an Irishman is an Englishman all the world over.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Mr. Leeson!

sp.speaker: MAID.
sp.p: O we shall have murder. running off.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Run into that room, my dear, and stay with the young lady, Exit Maid.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: And Connolly let nobody else into that room.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Let me alone for that, honey, if this gentleman has fifty people.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Whence is it, Mr. Belville, that you persecute me thus with injuries?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I am fill'd with astonishment!

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Faith, to speak the truth, you do look a little surpriz'd.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Answer me, Sir; what is the foundation of this new violence?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I am come, Mr. Leeson, upon an affair, Sir—

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: The devil burn me if he was half so much confounded a while ago, when there was a naked sword at his breast.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I am come, Mr. Leeson, upon an affair, Sir, that—How the devil shall I open it to him, since the tables are so fairly turn'd upon me.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Dispatch, Sir, for I have company in the next room.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: A lady, I suppose?

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Suppose it is, Sir?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: And the lady's name is Moreland, isn't it, Sir?

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: I can't see what business you have with her name, Sir, You took away my sister, and I hope you have no designs upon the lady in the next room.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Indeed but I have.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: The devil you have!

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Well, this is the most unaccountable man I ever heard of, he'll have all the women in the town, I believe.

sp.speaker: LEES,
sp.p: And pray, Sir, what pretensions, have you to the lady in the next room, even supposing her to be Miss Moreland?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: No other pretensions than what a brother should have to the defence of his sister's honour: You thought yourself authorised to cut my throat a-while ago in a similar business.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: And is Miss Moreland your sister?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Sir, there is insolence in that question; you know she is.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: By heaven, I did not know it till this moment; but I rejoice at the discovery: This is blow for blow!

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Devil burn me but they have fairly made a swop of it.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: And you really didn't know that Miss Moreland was my sister?

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p:
I don't conceive myself under much necessity of apologizing to you, Sir; but I am incapable of a dishonourable design upon any woman; and tho' Miss Moreland in our short acquaintance, repeatedly
mentioned her brother, she never once told me that his name was Belville.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: And he has had such few opportunities of being in her company, unless by letters, honey, that he knew nothing more of her connections, than her being a sweet pretty creter, and having 30,000 l.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: The fortune, I dare say, no way lessened the force of her attractions.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: I am above dissimulation—It really did not.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Leeson, our families have shewn such a very strong inclination to come together, that it would really be a pity to disappoint them.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Upon my soul and so it would; though the dread of being forc'd to have a husband, the young lady tells us, quicken'd her resolution to marry this gentleman.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: O she had no violence of that kind to apprehend from her family; therefore, Mr. Leeson, since you seem as necessary for the girl's happiness, as she seems for your's, you shall marry her here in town, with the consent of all her friends, and save yourself the trouble of an expedition to Scotland.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: Can I believe you serious?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Zounds, Leeson, that air of surprise is a sad reproach! I didn't surprise you when I did a bad action, but I raise your astonishment, when I do a good one.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: And by my soul, Mr. Belville, if you knew how a good action becomes a man, you'd never do a bad one as long as you liv'd.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: You have given me life and happiness in one day, Mr. Belville! however, it is now time you should see your sister; I know you'll be gentle with her, tho' you have so much reason to condemn her choice, and generously remember that her elopement proceeded from the great improbability there was of a beggar's ever meeting with the approbation of her family.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Don't apologize for your circumstances, Leeson; a princess could do no more than make you happy, and if you make her so, you meet her upon terms of the most perfect equality.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: This is a new way of thinking, Mr. Belville.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: 'Tis only an honest way of thinking, and I consider my sister a gainer upon the occasion; for a man of your merit is more difficult to be found, than a woman of her fortune. Exeunt Leeson and Belville.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: What's the reason now that I can't skip, and laugh, and rejoice, at this affair? Upon my soul my heart's as full as if I had met with some great misfortune. Well, pleasure in the extreme is certainly a very painful thing: I am really asham'd of these womans drops, and yet I don't know but that I ought to blush for being asham'd of them, for I am sure nobody's eye ever looks half so well, as when it is disfigured by a tear of humanity. Exit.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p:
WELL, happiness is once more mine, and the women are all going in tip-top spirits to the masquerade. Now, Mr. Belville, let me have a few words with you; Miss Walsingham, the ripe, the luxurious Miss Walsingham, expects to find you there burning with impatience:—But, my dear friend, after the occurrences of the day, can you be weak enough to plunge into fresh crimes? Can you be base
enough to abuse the goodness of that angel your wife; and wicked enough, not only to destroy the innocence which is shelter'd beneath your own roof, but to expose your family perhaps again, to the danger of losing a son, a brother, a father, and a husband? The possession of the three Graces is surely too poor a recompence for the folly you must commit, for the shame you must feel, and the consequences you must hazard. Upon my soul if I struggle a little longer, I shall rise in my own opinion, and be less a rascal than I think myself:—Ay, but the object is bewitching;—the matter will be an eternal secret—and if it is known that I sneak in this pitiful manner from a fine woman, when the whole elysium of her person solicits me:—well, and am I afraid the world should know that I have shrunk from an infamous action?—A thousand blessings on you dear conscience for that one argument;—I shall be an honest man after all—Suppose, however, that I give her the meeting; that's dangerous;—that's dangerous:—and I am so little accustomed to do what is right, that I shall certainly do what is wrong, the moment I am in the way of temptation. Come, Belville, your resolution is not so very slender a dependance, and you owe Miss Walsingham reparation for the injury which you have done her principles. I'll give her the meeting—I'll take her to the house I intended—I'll—Zounds! what a fool I have been all this time, to look for precarious satisfaction in vice, when there is such exquisite pleasure to be found at a certainty in virtue! Exit

div3.stage: Enter Lady Rachel and Mrs Belville.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: For mirth sake don't let him see us: There has been a warm debate between his passion and his conscience.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL
sp.p: And the latter is the conqueror, my life for it.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Dear Mrs. Belville you are the best of women, and ought to have the best of husbands.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: I have the best of husbands.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: I have not time to dispute the matter with you now; but I shall put you into my comedy to teach wives, that the best receipt for matrimonial happiness, is to be deaf, dumb, and blind.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Poh! poh! you are a satirest, Lady Rachel—But we are losing time; shou'dn't we put on our dresses, and prepare for the grand scene?

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Don't you tremble at the trial?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Not in the least, I am sure my heart has no occasion.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Have you let Miss Walsingham into our little plot?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: You know she cou'd not be insensible of Mr. Belville's design upon herself, and it is no farther than that design, we have any thing to carry into execution.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Well, she may serve to facilitate the matter, and therefore I am not sorry that you have trusted her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: We shall be too late, and then what signifies all your fine plotting.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Is it not a little pang of jealousy that wou'd fain now quicken our motions?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: No, Lady Rachel, it is a certainty of my husband's love and generosity, that makes me wish to come to the trial. I wou'd not exchange my confidence in his affections for all the mines of Peru; so nothing you can say will make me miserable.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: You are a most unaccountable woman; so away with you. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: Why, Ghastly, the old general your master is a greater fool than I ever thought he was: He want to marry Miss Walsingham?

sp.speaker: GHAST.
sp.p:
Mrs. Tempest suspected that there was
something going forward, by all his hugger-mugger consulting with Mr. Torrington; and so set me on to listen.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: She's a good friend of your's, and that thing she made the General give you the other day in the hospital, is I suppose a snug hundred a year.

sp.speaker: GHAST.
sp.p: Better than two; I wash for near four thousand people: there was a major of horse who put in for it, and pleaded a large family—

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: With long services, I suppose.

sp.speaker: GHAST.
sp.p: Yes, but Mrs. Tempest insisted upon my long services; so the major was set aside—However to keep the thing from the damn'd News-papers, I fancy he will succeed the barber, who died last night, poor woman, of a lying-in fever, after being brought to bed of three children,—Places in public institutions.—

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: Are often sweetly dispos'd I think of asking Belville for something, one of these days.

sp.speaker: GHAST.
sp.p: He has great interest.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: I might be a justice of peace; if I pleased, and in a shabby neighbourhood, where the mere swearing would bring in something tolerable; but there are so many strange people let into the commission now-a-days, that I shou'dn't like to have my name in the list.

sp.speaker: GHAST.
sp.p: You are right.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: No, no, I leave that to paltry tradesmen, and shall think of some little sinecure, or a small pension on the Irish establishment.

sp.speaker: GHAST.
sp.p: Well, success attend you. I must hobble home as fast as I can, to know if Mrs. Tempest has any orders. O, there's a rare storm brewing for our old goat of a General.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: When shall we crack a bottle together?

sp.speaker: GHAST.
sp.p:
O, I shan't touch a glass of Claret these three weeks; for last night I gave nature a little fillip with a drunken bout, according to the doctor's directions; I have entirely left off bread, and I am in great hopes that I shall get rid of my gout by these means,
specially if I can learn to eat my meat quite raw like a cannibal.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: GHAST.
sp.p: Look at me, Spruce, I was once as likely a young fellow as any under ground in the whole parish of St. James's:—but waiting on the General so many years.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: Ay, and following his example, Ghastly.

sp.speaker: GHAST.
sp.p: 'Tis too true: has reduc'd me to what you see. These miserable spindles wou'd do very well for a lord or a duke, Spruce; but they are a sad disgrace to a poor valet de chambre. Exit.

sp.speaker: SPRUCE.
sp.p: Well, I don't believe there's a gentleman's gentleman within the weekly bills, who joins a prudent solicitude for the main-chance, to a strict care of his constitution, better than myself. I have a little girl who stands me in about three guineas a week; I never bet more than a pound upon a rubber of whist; I always sleep with my head very warm; and swallow a new laid egg every morning with my chocolate. Exit.

head.stage: The Scene changes to the Street, two Chairs cross the Stage, knock at a Door, and set down BELVILLE and a Lady.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: This way, my dear creature! Exeunt.

div3.stage: Enter Gen. Savage, Capt. Savage, and Torrington.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: There! there they go in:—You see the place is quite convenient, not twenty yards from the masquerade.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: How closely the fellow sticks to her.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Like the great seal to the peerage patent of a chancellor. But, gentlemen, we have still no more than proof presumptive:—where is the ocular demonstration which we were to have?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: I'll swear to the blue domino; 'tis a very remarkable one, and so is Belville's.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p:
You wou'd have rare custom among the New-gate
sollicitors, if you'd venture an oath upon the identity of the party under it.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: 'Tis the very size and shape of Miss Walsingham.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: And yet I have a strange notion that there is a trifling alibi in this case.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: It wou'd be a damn'd affair if we shou'd be countermin'd.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: O, follow me, here's the door left luckily open, and I'll soon clear up the matter beyond a question. Enters the house.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Why your son is mad, General. This must produce a deadly breach with Belville. For heav'n's sake, let's go in and prevent any excesses of his rashness.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: By all means, or the poor fellow's generous anxiety on my account may be productive of very fatal consequences. Exeunt.

head.stage: The Scene changes to an aparment, Belville unmasked, and a lady in a blue domino mask'd.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: My dear Miss Walsingham, we are now perfectly safe, yet I will by no means intreat you to unmask, because I am convinc'd, from the propriety with which you repuls'd my addresses this morning, that you intend the present interview should make me still more deeply sensible of my presumption.—I never lied so aukwardly in all my life; if it was to make her comply, I should be at no loss for language. (aside) The situation in which I must appear before you, Madam, is certainly a very humiliating one; but I am persuaded that your generosity will be gratified to hear, that I have bid an everlasting adieu to my profligacy, and am now only alive to the virtues of Mrs. Belville.—She won't speak—I don't wonder at it, for brazen as I am myself, if I met so mortifying a rejection, I should be cursedly out of countenance.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: (behind) I will go in.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: (behind.) I command you to desist.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: (behind.) This will be an affair for the Old-Bailey.

div3.stage: The noise grows more violent, and continues.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Why, what the devil is all this?—Don't be alarm'd, Miss Walsingham, be assur'd I'll protect you at the hazard of my life;—step into this closet,— you shan't be discover'd depend upon it; (she goes in): And now to find out the cause of this confusion. unlocks the door.

div3.stage: Enter Gen. Savage, Capt. Savage, and Torrington.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Savage! what is the meaning of this strange behaviour?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Where is Miss Walsingham?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: So then, Sir, this is a premeditated scheme, for which I am oblig'd to your friendship.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Where's Miss Walsingham, Sir?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Dear Belville, he is out of his senses; this storm was entirely against my orders.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: If he proceeds much longer in these vagaries, we must amuse him with a commission of lunacy.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: This is neither a time nor a place for argument, Mr. Torrington; but as you and the General seem to be in the possession of your senses, I shall be glad if you'll take this very friendly gentleman away; and depend upon it, I shan't die in his debt for the present obligation.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: And depend upon it, Sir, pay the obligation when you will, I shan't stir 'till I see Miss Walsingham.—Look'ee, Belville, there are secret reasons for my behaving in this manner; reasons, which you yourself will approve, when you know them;—my father here—

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Disavows your conduct in every particular, and would rejoice to see you at the halberds.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: And, for my part, I told him previously 'twas a downright burglary.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Well, gentlemen, let your different motives for breaking in upon me in this agreeable manner, be what they may, I don't see that I am less annoy'd by my friends than my enemy. I must therefore again, request that you will all walk down stairs.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: I'll first walk into this room.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Really, I think you will not.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: What phrenzy possesses the fellow to urge this matter farther?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
BEL.
sp.p: Then you must make your way thro' me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: There, I knew she was in the room:— there's the blue domino.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Put up your sword, if you don't desire to be cashier'd from my favour for ever.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Why, wou'd you come out, madam? But, you have nothing to apprehend.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Pray, madam, will you have the goodness to unmask?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: She shan't unmask.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: I say she shall.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I say she shall not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Pray, let me oblige the gentleman?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Death and destruction, here's a discovery!

sp.speaker: GEN. and TOR.
sp.p: Mrs. Belville!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Yes, Mrs. Belville, gentlemen: Is consugal fidelity so very terrible a thing now a-days, that a man is to suffer death for being found in company with his own wife?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: My love, this is a surprize, indeed—But it is a most agreeable one; since you find me really asham'd of my former follies, and cannot now doubt the sincerity of my reformation.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: I am too happy! this single moment wou'd over pay a whole life of anxiety.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Where shall I attend you? Will you return to the masquerade?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: O no! Lady Rachel and Miss Walsingham are by this time at our house, with Mr. Leeson and the Irish gentleman whom you press'd into our party, impatiently expecting the result of this adventure.

sp.speaker: BEL.
Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: And when you next disturb a téte a téte, for pity to a poor wife, don't let it be so very uncustomary a party, as the matrimonial one.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: (to the Capt.) So, Sir, you have led us upon a blessed expedition here.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Now, don't you think that if your courts of honour, like our courts of law, search'd a little minutely into evidence, it wou'd be equally to the credit of their understandings?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Tho' I am cover'd with confusion at my mistake (for you see, Belville was mistaken as well as myself,) I am overjoy'd at this discovery of Miss Walsingham's innocence.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I shou'd exult in it too, with a feu de joy, if it didn't now shew the impossibility of her ever being Mrs. Savage.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Dear Sir, why should you think that an impossibility? Tho' some mistakes have occurr'd consequence I suppose, of Mrs. Belville's little plot upon her husband, I dare say Miss Walsingham may yet be prevail'd upon to come into our family.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Take care of a new error in your proceedings, young gentleman.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Ay, another defeat would make us compleatly despicable.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Sir, I'll forseit my life, if she does not consent to the marriage this very night.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Only bring this matter to bear, and I'll forgive you every thing.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: The Captain shou'd be inform'd, I think General, that she declin'd it peremptorily this evening.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Ay, do you hear that, Horace?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: I am not at all surpriz'd at it, considering the general misconception we labour'd under. But I'll immediately to Belville's, explain the whole mystery, and conclude every thing to your satisfaction. Exit.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: So, Torrington, we shall be able to take the field again, you see.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: But how in the name of wonder has your son found out your intention of marrying Miss Walsingham? I look'd upon myself as the only person acquainted with the secret.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: That thought has march'd itself two or three times to my own recollection. For tho' I gave him some distant hints of the affair, I took particular care to keep behind the works of a proper circumspection.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: O, if you gave him any hints at all, I am not surpriz'd at his discovering every thing.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I shall be all impatience 'till I hear of his interview with Miss Walsingham: Suppose my dear friend we went to Belville's, 'tis but in the next street, and we shall be there in the lighting of a match.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Really this is a pretty business for a man of my age and profession, trot here, trot there. But, as I have been weak enough to make myself a kind of party in the cause, I own that I have curiosity enough to be anxious about the determination.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Come along my old boy; and remember the song, "Servile spirits, &c." Exeunt.

div3.stage: Enter Captain Savage and Miss Walsingham.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Nay, but my dearest Miss Walsingham, the extenuation of my own conduct to Belville made it absolutely necessary for me to discover my engagements with you; and as happiness is now so fortunately in our reach, I flatter myself you will be prevail'd upon to forgive an error, which proceeded only from an extravagance of love.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: To think me capable of such an action, Captain Savage! I am terrified at the idea of a union with you, and it is better for a woman at any time, to sacrifice an insolent lover, than to accept of a suspicious husband.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: In the happiest unions, my dearest creature, there must be always something to overlook on both sides.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Very civil, truly.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Pardon me, my life, for this frankness; and recollect, that if the lover has thro' misconception been unhappily guilty, he brings a husband altogether reform'd to your hands.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Well, I see I must forgive you at last, so I may as well make a merit of necessity, you provoking creature.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: And may I hope, indeed, for the blessing of this hand?

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Why, you wretch, would you have me force it upon you? I think, after what I have said, a soldier might have ventur'd to take it without farther ceremony.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Angelic creature! thus I seize it as my lawful prize.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Well, but now you have obtained this inestimable prize, Captain, give me again leave to ask if you have had a certain explanation with the General?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: How can you doubt it?

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: And he is really impatient for our marriage?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: 'Tis incredible how earnest he is.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: What, did he tell you of his Interview with me this evening, when he brought Mr. Torrington?

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: He did.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: O, then, I can have do doubt.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: If a shadow of doubt remains, here he comes to remove it. Joy, my dear Sir! joy a thousand times!

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: What, my dear boy, have you carried the day?

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: I have been weak enough to indulge him with a victory, indeed, General.

p.hi: None but the brave, none but the brave, &c.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: I congratulate you heartily on this decree, General.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: This had nearly proved a day of disappointment, but the stars have fortunately turn'd it in my favour, and now I reap the rich reward of my victory. (Salutes her)

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: And here I take her from you, as the greatest good which heav'n can send me.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: O, Captain!

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: You take her as the greatest good which heav'n can send you, sirrah; I take her as the greatest good which heav'n can send me: And now what have you to say to her?

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: General Savage!

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Here will be a fresh injunction to stop proceedings.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Are we never to have done with mistakes?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: What mistakes can have happen'd now my sweetest? you deliver'd up your dear hand to me this moment?

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: True, Sir; but I thought you were going to bestow my dear hand upon this dear gentleman.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: How! that dear gentleman!

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: I am thunder-struck!

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: General—None but the brave, &c. sings.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: So the covert way is clear'd at last; and you have imagin'd that I was all along negociating for this fellow, when I was gravely soliciting for myself?

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: No other idea, Sir, ever once enter'd my imagination.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: General.—Noble minds should ne'er despair, &c. sings.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Zounds! here's all the company pouring upon us in full gallop, and I shall be the laughing stock of the whole town.

div3.stage: Enter Belville, Mrs. Belville, Lady Rachel, Leeson and Connolly.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: Well, General, we have left you a long time together. Shall I give you joy?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: No; wish me demolish'd in the fortifications of Dunkirk.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: The General appears disconcerted.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: The gentleman looks as if he had fought a hard battle.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Ay, and gain'd nothing but a defeat, my dear.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: I'll shew cause for his behaviour.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Death and damnation! not for the world. I am taken by surprise here; let me consider a moment how to cut my way thro' the enemy.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: How cou'd you be deceiv'd in this manner. To Capt.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: O, Mr. Torrington, we are much oblig'd to you; you have been in town ever since last night, and only see us now by accident.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: I have been very busy, Madam; but you look sadly, very sadly indeed! your old disorder the jaundice, I suppose, has been very troublesome to you?

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Sir, you have a very extraordinary mode of complimenting your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: I don't believe for all that, that there's a word of a lie in the truth he speaks. aside

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Miss Walsingham, Capt. Savage has been telling Mr. Belville and me of a very extraordinary mistake.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: 'Tis very strange indeed, mistake on mistake.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: 'Tis no way strange to find every body properly struck with the merit of Miss Walsingham.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: A compliment from you now, Mr. Belville, is really worth accepting.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: If I thought the affair cou'd be kept a secret, by making the town over to my son, since I am utterly shut out myself—

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: He seems exceedingly embarrassed.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: If I thought that;—why mortified as I must be in giving it up, I think I cou'd resolve upon the manoeuvre, to save myself from universal ridicule: but it can't be;—it can't be; and I only double my own disappointment in rewarding the disobedience of the rascal who has supplanted me. There!—there! they are all talking of it, all laughing at me, and I shall run mad!

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEMP.
sp.p: (behind) I say, you feather-headed puppy, he is in this house; my own servant saw him come in, and I will not stir 'till I find him.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: She here!—then deliberation is over, and I am entirely blown up.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: I'll take notes of this affair.

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEMP.
sp.p: Mighty well, Sir. So you are in love it seems;—and you want to be married it seems?

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: My blessed aunt!—O how proud I am of the relation.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Dear Bab, give me quarter before all this company.

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEMP.
sp.p: You are in love, you old fool, are you? and you want to marry Miss Walsingham, indeed!

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: I never heard a pleasanter spoken gentlewoman —O hone, if I had the taming of her, she shou'd never be abusive, without keeping a civil tongue in her head.

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEM.
sp.p: Well, Sir, and when is the happy day to be fix'd?

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: What the devil, is this true, General?

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: True.—Can you believe such an absurdity?

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEMP.
sp.p: Why, will you deny, you miserable old mummy, that you made proposal of marriage to her?—

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Yes I do—no I don't—proposals of marriage!

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: In favour of your son.—I'll help him out a little. aside

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Yes, in favour of my son—what the devil shall I do?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Shall I take a lesson from this lady, Mr. Belville? Perhaps if the women of virtue were to pluck up a little spirit, they might be soon as well treated as kept mistresses.

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEMP.
sp.p: Harkee, General Savage, I believe you assert a falsehood; but if you speak the truth, give your son this moment to Miss Walsingham, and let me be fairly rid of my rival.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: My son! Miss Walsingham!—Miss Walsingham, my son!

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: It will do, Horace; it will do.

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEMP.
sp.p: No prevarications, General Savage; do what I bid you instantly, or by all the wrongs of an enraged woman, I'll so expose you.—

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: What a fine fellow this is, to have the command of an army!

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: If Miss Walsingham can be prevailed upon.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: O, she'll oblige you readily—But you must settle a good fortune upon your son.

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEMP.
sp.p: That he shall do.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: Miss Walsingham, my Dear—

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: I can refuse nothing either to your request, or to the request of the General.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Oblige me with your hand then, Madam: come here you—come here Captain. There, there is Miss Walsingham's hand for you.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: And as pretty a little fist it is, as any in the three kingdoms.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: Torrington shall settle the fortune.

sp.speaker: LEES.
sp.p: I give you joy most heartily, Madam.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: We all give her joy.

sp.speaker: CAPT.
sp.p: Mine is beyond the power of expression.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: (aside to the company) And so is the General's, I believe.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: O faith, that may be easily seen by the sweetness of his countenance.

sp.speaker: TOR.
sp.p: Well, the cause being now at last determin'd, I think we may all retire from the court.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: And without any great credit, I fear, to the General.

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: By my soul, you may say that.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. TEMP.
sp.p: Do you murmur, Sir?—Come this moment home with me.

sp.speaker: GEN.
sp.p: I'll go any where to hide this miserable head of mine: what a damn'd campaign have I made of it!

sp.speaker: CON.
sp.p: Upon my soul, if I was in the General's place, I'd divide the house with this devil; I'd keep within doors myself, and make her take the outside.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: The day has been a busy one, thanks to the communicative disposition of the Captain.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BEL.
sp.p: And the evening should be chearful.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: I shan't therefore part with one of you, 'till we have had a hearty laugh at our general adventures.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: They have been very whimsical indeed; yet if represented on the stage, I hope they wou'd be found not only entertaining, but instructive.

sp.speaker: Lady RACH.
sp.p: Instructive! why the modern Critics say that the only business of Comedy is to make people laugh.

sp.speaker: BEL.
sp.p: That is degrading the dignity of letters exceedingly, as well as lessening the utility of the stage —A good comedy is a capital effort of genius, and should therefore be directed to the noblest purposes.

sp.speaker: Miss WAL.
sp.p: Very true; and unless we learn something while we chuckle, the carpenter who nails a Pantomime together, will be entitled to more applause, than the best comic poet in the kingdom.
